proverb: The Andes are the longest continental mountain range in the world, forming a continuous highland along the western edge of South America.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with mountain ranges and continents

proverb: I lived and worked in Australia for a whole year. The last three months were the best because I got to travel around the country!
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use last or the last

proverb: I don't like chicken, but I like the chicken that my mother cooks.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about something specific. 'chicken' can act both as count (bird) and uncount noun (meat - курятина). In this example chicken is an uncountable noun.

proverb: I like cake, but I don't like the cake you make.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about something specific. Also, the noun 'cake' can be either countable and uncountable. In this sentence 'cake' is an uncountable noun.

proverb: We wanted to watch TV, but there wasn't one in the apartment, so we just listened to the radio.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the definite article. We always use the definite article with 'radio': listen to the radio, hear on the radio, it's on the radio

proverb: Please, read the text on page 15.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the definite article. We do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: I visited South Africa last summer.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use last or the last

proverb: Our children go to school by bus.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions

proverb: Christmas comes but once a year, but when it comes it brings good cheer.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definine article with the names of holidays

proverb: Images may be subject to copyright.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to pronounce 'subject' as an adjective

proverb: Life is beautiful. The life of wise people is beautiful.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article when talking about something specific. In these examples life is an uncount noun, but in the first example we are talking about life in general, and in the second example we are talking about the life of wise people, which is specific

proverb: Friendship is precious. The friendship of those two children is precious.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article when talking about something specific. In these examples friendship is an uncount noun, but in the first example we are talking about friendship in general, and in the second example we are talking about the friendship of two kids, which is specific

proverb: We need furniture. They decided to sell the furniture.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article when talking about something specific. It also demonstrates that 'furniture' is an uncountable noun

proverb: I want to make money. I want to make the money I need to pay my rent.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article when talking about something specific. It also demonstrates that 'money' is an uncountable noun

proverb: Snow is cold. The snow in this city is so white.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about something specific. It also demonstrates that 'snow' is an uncountable noun

proverb: There's a lamp in my room. The lamp shines too bright.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about something specific. The second time we talk about the same thing in a phrase, we have to use 'the' with it

proverb: Next month will be busy.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use next or the next.

proverb: I have a doctor's appointment next week.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use next or the next

proverb: The last month has been amazing.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use last or the last. Here we are talking about the time period (the last 30 days), that's why the PP is used

proverb: In the last two minutes, Paul has eaten four hot dogs.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use last or the last. Here we are talking about the time period (за последние две минуты), that's why the PP is used

proverb: The next two weeks will be tough!
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use next or the next. Here we are talking about the next 14 days

proverb: I had lunch with her last Wednesday.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use last or the last, and also that lunch is an uncountable noun

proverb: The husband is always the last to know.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use last or the last

proverb: Last time we got together, it was a disaster. The last time we got together, it was a disaster.
description: These sentences show that we can use 'last time' or 'the last time' interchangeably

proverb: I went to London last June.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use last or the last

proverb: I can't wait for next summer!
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use next or the next

proverb: Where were you last night? I called you three times.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use last or the last

proverb: I'm planning to do it in the next 10 minutes.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use next or the next

proverb: Most dogs have tails.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'most' or 'the most'. We use 'most' without 'the' when we talk about 90% of something. Notice that here 'most' is an adjective, but it is not a superlative adjective

proverb: Most students passed the test.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'most' or 'the most'. We use 'most' without 'the' when we talk about 90% of something. Notice that here 'most' is an adjective, but it is not a superlative adjective

proverb: I like this one most.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'most' or 'the most'. We use 'most' without 'the' when we want to express preference. Notice that here 'most' is an adverb, it describes the verb 'like', so the rule about needing 'the' with superlative adjectives does not apply here

proverb: What matters most to you?
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'most' or 'the most'. We use 'most' without 'the' when we want to express preference. Notice that here 'most' is an adverb (matters most), it describes the verb 'matter', so the rule about needing 'the' with superlative adjectives does not apply here. By the way, this is a subject question

proverb: The kids loved the fair, but they enjoyed the bumper cars most of all.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'most' or 'the most'. We use 'most' without 'the' when we want to express preference. Notice that here 'most' is an adverb (enjoyed most), so the rule about needing 'the' with superlative adjectives does not apply here

proverb: He is the most famous actor I know.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'most' or 'the most'. We use 'the most' with some superlative adjectives, or when we want to describe the biggest number or amount of something, or something of the greatest importance, strength, value, etc. Here 'most' is part of a superlative adjective

proverb: It's a lovely day - we must make the most of it.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'most' or 'the most'. We use 'the most' with some superlative adjectives, or when we want to describe the biggest number or amount of something, or something of the greatest importance, strength, value, etc. Here 'most' is a noun and 'to make the most of something' is a set expression and it means - извлекать максимальную пользу/выгоду из чего-то

proverb: Which of you earns the most money?
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'most' or 'the most'. We use 'the most' with some superlative adjectives, or when we want to describe the biggest number or amount of something, or something of the greatest importance, strength, value, etc. There are other similar expressions: make the most, get the most, earn the most, etc and in all of them 'most' is a noun, not an adverb or an adjective. Also we don't usually use 'which' with people but it is often used in such questions: Which of you did this? Which doctor did you see? Which of you want tea and which want lemonade?, etc

proverb: This juice is most delicious if you chill it for a long time first. Which juice is the most delicious? Apple juice, orange juice or raspberry juice?
description: These sentences demonstrate when to use 'most' or 'the most'. In the first sentence 'most' is an adverb that describes the adjective 'delicious' and means to a great extent, can be replaced with 'very': This juice is very delicious ... In the second sentence 'most' is part of a superlative adjective which consists of more than two syllables

proverb: advantage but advantageous
description: This expression demonstrates how to pronounce advantage and advantageous in American English

proverb: courage but courageous
description: This expression demonstrates how to pronounce courage and courageous in American English

proverb: The Philippines is visited by an average of 20 typhoons annually.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with country names. In most cases we do not use 'the' with country names, but we use it when a country has a political title in its name (united, republic, kingdom, empire), or if a name has plural meaning (The Netherlands, The Philippines, the Canary Islands). Notice that even though the Philippines has plural meaning it is followed by 'is' because here we're talking about the country. But sometimes it can be followed by 'are' when it refers to an island archipelago

proverb: The Republic of Ireland is in the European Union.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with country names. In most cases we do not use ‘the’ with country names, but we use it when a country has a political title in its name (united, republic, kingdom, empire), or if a name has plural meaning (The Netherlands, The Philippines, the Canary Islands)

proverb: We're going on vacation to the Dominican Republic.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with country names. In most cases we do not use ‘the’ with country names, but we use it when a country has a political title in its name (united, republic, kingdom, empire), or if a name has plural meaning (The Netherlands, The Philippines, the Canary Islands)

proverb: We took a trip down the Nile.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of rivers

proverb: Mordor Orcs now hold the eastern shore of the Anduin.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of rivers

proverb: The Danube is Austria's longest river.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of rivers, and also when to use the possessive case

proverb: We flew over the Atlantic.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with oceans

proverb: The Baltic Sea is north of Poland.
description: We use the definite article with the names of seas. Also we do not use the definite article when refering to West, East, North or South as directions. Here 'north' is an adverb, it describes the verb 'is' (к северу, на север, в северном направлении)

proverb: The Sahara is the world's biggest desert.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with deserts. It also demonstrates when to use the possessive 's

proverb: She has never been to the Alps before.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with mountain ranges

proverb: Mount Everest is in the Himalayas.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with single mountains and with mountain ranges

proverb: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on earth.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with single mountains. Also notice that here 'earth' means the world, not the planet, that's why it is not capitalized

proverb: Jamaica belongs to the Caribbean islands.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with groups of islands and with single islands. It also demonstrates that the verb 'belong' is a stative verb.

proverb: The Taj Mahal is one of India's most popular attractions.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with famous landmarks

proverb: A man and woman standing in front of the Eiffel Tower.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with famous landmarks

proverb: I live in the west of the city.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when referring to the West, North, East or South as geographical parts of something (not directions).

proverb: Egypt is in the north of Africa.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when referring to the West, North, East or South as geographical parts of something (not directions).

proverb: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when referring to the West, North, East or South as geographical parts of something. But when we refer to the West, East, North or South as directions we don't use the definite article: 'I am traveling north'

proverb: Every year we would go to the south of France for holidays.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when referring to the West, North, East or South as geographical parts of something. Also notice that here the modal would is used to talk about a habitual action in the past (similar to used to): We used to go to the south of France for holidays every year.

proverb: I'm traveling north.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when we refer to West, East, North or South as directions. Here 'north' is an adverb. Also, 'traveling' is the preferred spelling in American English, in British English the preferred spelling is 'travelling'

proverb: The Nile is the longest river in Africa. It flows north from Lake Victoria to the Mediterranean Sea.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article with bodies of water and also when we refer to West, East, North or South as directions. Here 'north' is an adverb and it describes the verb 'flow' (течет на север)

proverb: We're having dinner with the Smiths tonight.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with family names in the plural form. Also the verb 'have' is used in the continuous form here and means 'experiencing' or 'taking', although it is usually used as a stative verb.

proverb: Our friends, the Millers, moved to Florida last August.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with family names in the plural form. It also demonstrates when to use 'last' or 'the last'

proverb: She works for the New York Times.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with newspaper names

proverb: He's staying at the Hilton hotel in room 221. My sister often stays at Uncle Tim's in Detroit.
description: These sentences demonstrate that the definite article is used with the names of hotels (and also pubs and restaurants), but not when they are named after their owners/founders. If a hotel/pub/restaurant is named after someone we don't use 'the' in front of it. Think of it as that person's place or house. We often say: I am at John's or she is at her aunt's (the implication being John's house or aunt's house). The same idea here. Shops are also often named after their owners and the rule is the same: I'll buy some bread at Smith's

proverb: At the Prancing Pony, an inn in the village of Bree, Frodo received a delayed letter from Gandalf. My sister often stays at Uncle Tim's in Detroit.
description: These sentences demonstrate that the definite article is used with pubs, restaurants and hotels also, but not when they are named after their owners/founders. If a hotel/pub/restaurant is named after someone we don't use 'the' in front of it. Think of it as that person's place or house. We often say: I am at John's or she is at her aunt's (the implication being John's house or aunt's house). The same idea here (McDonald's is also used without 'the'). Shops are also often named after their owners and the rule is the same: I'll buy some bread at Smith's

proverb: He who rides a tiger can never get off.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we can ride something if we are on top of it (ride a bicycle, horse, bike, etc). It also demonstrates that we use the transportation prepositions 'on' and 'off' when we ride something: 'get on', 'get off'. These prepositions are also used with means of transport which are considered a platform (bus, train, ship, etc)

proverb: She was at the cinema at the moment the crime was committed.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with cinemas and theaters

proverb: Sarah wants to go to the cinema on Friday.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with cinemas and theaters. 'go to the cinema - пойти в кино' is a set expression where we always use the definite article

proverb: The Academy Awards, more popularly known as the Oscars, are awards for artistic and technical merit in the film industry.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with awards, prizes, orders and medals

proverb: Einstein was awarded the Nobel prize in 1922.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with awards, prizes, orders and medals

proverb: The Order of the Red Banner was the first Soviet military decoration.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with awards, prizes, orders and medals

proverb: Madame Tussaud's is London's most famous tourist attraction.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use most or the most. Here 'most' is an adverb that describes the adjective 'famous'. It seems like we have a superlative adjective here. But we can't say: Madame Tussaud's is London's the most famous tourist attraction; it sounds weird. We can't also say: Madame Tussaud's is the London's most famous tourist attraction, because we can't use 'the' with London, it is a proper noun. But we can say: The most famous tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's. It also demonstrates when to use the possessive case.

proverb: Smoking causes cancer.
description: This sentence demonstrates uncountable nouns

proverb: I have too many clothes. I have too much clothing.
description: These sentences demonstrate the difference between clothes and clothing (clothes is count noun, whereas clothing is uncount). Also 'clothes' is a collective plural without a singular form

proverb: The news is so shocking!
description: This sentence demonstrates irregular singular nouns

proverb: There's good news and bad news.
description: 'news' is an irregular uncountable singular noun. Irregular singular nouns are nouns that end with 's' but they are singular (Есть хорошая новость и есть плохая новость)

proverb: Physics is fascinating.
description: This sentence demonstrates irregular singular nouns

proverb: Some people say that politics is dirty.
description: This sentence demonstrates irregular singular nouns. 'politics' is an irregular uncountable singular noun. Other examples: economics, physics, news, Mathematics, athletics, billiards, statistics, etc. There are also some diseases: mumps, measles, rabies, etc

proverb: Statistics is an important subject relevant to various fields.
description: This sentence demonstrates irregular singular nouns. 'statistics' is an irregular uncountable singular noun. Other examples: economics, politics, physics, news, Mathematics, athletics, billiards, etc. There are also some diseases: mumps, measles, rabies, etc

proverb: Billiards is easier than pool or snooker.
description: This sentence demonstrates irregular singular nouns

proverb: Measles is a highly contagious infectious disease.
description: This sentence demonstrates irregular singular nouns

proverb: Five dollars is all that I have.
description: This sentence demonstrates that quantities of money, time and distance are considered singular nouns

proverb: Eight hours is a normal working day.
description: This sentence demonstrates that quantities of money, time and distance are considered singular nouns

proverb: Five miles is too far to walk.
description: This sentence demonstrates that quantities of money, time and distance are considered singular nouns

proverb: I love playing the guitar. Mike's mother bought him a guitar for his birthday.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article with musical instrument. We use 'the' when we're talking about actually playing an instrument (the ability to play).

proverb: I'm learning to play the piano. We bought a new piano.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article with musical instrument. We use 'the' when we're talking about actually playing an instrument (the ability to play).

proverb: The dollar is a strong currency.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with currencies

proverb: On the foreign exchanges the pound rose two cents against the dollar.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with currencies

proverb: The rose is my favorite flower.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with plants or animals, when a singular animal or plant is meant to represent a whole class. Here we are not talking about a specific rose

proverb: The tiger lives in Asia.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with plants or animals, when a singular animal or plant is meant to represent a whole class (here we are not talking about a specific tiger)

proverb: The cheetah achieves by far the fastest land speed of any living animal.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with plants or animals, when a singular animal or plant is meant to represent a whole class (here we are not talking about a specific cheetah)

proverb: Go home and come back in a week's time.
description: We use the possessive 's not only with animate items (people, animals), but also with places (country, city, somebody's house) and  organizations/teams/companies. The possessive -'s can also be used in time expressions (yesterday's party, today's news, last year's conference, three days' drive, etc).

proverb: Are you coming to Sunday's party?
description: We use the possessive 's not only with animate items (people, animals), but also with places (country, city, somebody's house) and  organizations/teams/companies. The possessive -'s can also be used in time expressions (yesterday's party, today's news, last year's conference, three days' drive, etc).

proverb: Did you read yesterday's newspaper?
description: We use the possessive 's not only with animate items (people, animals), but also with places (country, city, somebody's house) and  organizations/teams/companies. The possessive -'s can also be used in time expressions (yesterday's party, today's news, last year's conference, three days' drive, etc).

proverb: Australia's economy has slowed to its most sluggish pace since 2009.
description: We use the possessive 's not only with animate items (people, animals), but also with places (country, city) and  organizations/teams/companies. The possessive -'s can also be used in time expressions (yesterday's party, today's news, last year's conference, three days' drive, etc).

proverb: The team's lack of ambition is disappointing.
description: We use the possessive 's not only with animate items (people, animals), but also with places (country, city) and  organizations/teams/companies. The possessive -'s can also be used in time expressions (yesterday's party, today's news, last year's conference, three days' drive, etc).

proverb: The company's head office is on Park Avenue.
description: We use the possessive 's not only with animate items (people, animals), but also with places (country, city) and organizations/teams/companies. The possessive -'s can also be used in time expressions (yesterday's party, today's news, last year's conference, three days' drive, etc).

proverb: The Dutch live in the Netherlands.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about nations

proverb: The English are known as a seafaring people.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about nations

proverb: The French are known for their food and wine. We were attacked by French. We were attacked by a Frenchman.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article when talking about nations. In the first sentence we're talking about the whole nation. In the second sentence we're talking about a group of people of a certain nationality (на нас напало несколько французов, а не вся французская нация). And in the third sentece we're talking about one person of a certain nationality (на нас напал один францус)

proverb: The rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about particular groups of people within society

proverb: Will the meek inherit the earth?
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about particular groups of people within society

proverb: The dead outnumber the living.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about particular groups of people within society

proverb: She works for a group to help the disabled.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about particular groups of people within society. Other examples: the young, the old, the dead, the living, the rich, the poor, the blind, the righteous etc

proverb: Cell phones are especially popular with the young.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about particular groups of people within society

proverb: They are collecting money to help the homeless.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article when talking about particular groups of people within society

proverb: It happened in the 16th century.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with centuries, decades and historic periods

proverb: Great Wizards of the Twentieth Century is a book about prominent wizards during the 20th century.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with centuries, decades and historic periods

proverb: He grew up in the seventies.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with centuries, decades and historic periods

proverb: It happened in the Middle Ages.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with centuries, decades and historic periods

proverb: I often listen to the radio in my car.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article (we always use the definite article with 'radio')

proverb: The police are coming, we must go! The police are working on the case. The police have left the crime scene.
description: 'Police' is normally a plural, collective noun, so we always say 'The police are', but it can be followed by singular verbs when it is thought of as a single unit (The police force, the Police Department). These sentences also demonstrate that we always use the definite article with 'police'

proverb: I grew up in the country.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we always say 'the country' when we mean a rural area (сельская местность в широком смысле). It also demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with enclosed spaces

proverb: John lives in a small town in the country.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we always say 'the country' when we mean a rural area in general (сельская местность в широком смысле). It also demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with enclosed spaces

proverb: I've never been to the mountains. They usually spend their holidays in the mountains.
description: When we talk about mountains in broad terms (горная местность, горы в широком смысле), we say 'the mountains'. Similar examples: I've never been to the sea (Я никогда не был на море), I prefer to live in the country instead of the town (Я предпочитаю жить в сельской местности чем в городе). These are set expressions

proverb: Because of rain, we couldn't go to the beach.
description: This sentence demonstrates a set expression 'go to the beach - пойти на пляж'

proverb: I spent the entire day on the beach.
description: This sentence demonstrates a set expression 'on the beach' which means the sand. 'At the beach' is a little more general, if you say 'I spent the entire day at the beach' it means that you could have been in the water, or at a shop near the beach buying ice cream, or even on vacation in a beach town. 'on the beach' means you were actually sitting, walking or lying on the sand.

proverb: We had a good time at the beach yesterday.
description: This sentence demonstrates the difference between 'at the beach' and 'on the beach'. 'On the beach' means you are literally on the sand near the water. 'At the beach' is more general and could mean you're literally on the sand, or in the water, or it could mean you're visiting a beach town. To better understand 'We had a good time at the beach yesterday: we swam, played volleyball and then had a couple of beers at a nearby pub'

proverb: Let's meet at the beach. Let's meet on the beach.
description: 'at' is more general, it refers to the general vicinity of the beach. On the other hand, 'on' is more specific, it refers to the sand near the water.

proverb: The boy is afraid to go to bed in the dark.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we always say 'in the dark'

proverb: Let's go to the beach!
description: This sentence demonstrates a set expression 'go to the beach - пойти на пляж'

proverb: I'm going to Europe next month on vacation.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with geographical names, and also when to use 'next' or 'the next'

proverb: Seoul is the capital of South Korea.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with geographical names

proverb: The Plaza Hotel is on the corner of 59th Street and 5th Avenue.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of hotels, and also how to use prepositions of place

proverb: He's homeless and lives on the streets.
description: This sentence demonstrates a set expression 'to live on the streets'

proverb: I want to climb Mount Fuji.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with geographical names (single mountains)

proverb: Madagascar is an island located in the western Indian Ocean. Lemurs are native only to the island of Madagascar.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article with geographical names (single islands, oceans)

proverb: Lake Ontario and Lake Huron are two of the Great Lakes.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with geographical names (single lakes, groups of lakes)

proverb: Loch Ness is the most famous lake in Scotland.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with geographical names (single lakes, country names)

proverb: I live by the lake.
description: This sentence demonstrates a set expression 'by the lake - у озера'

proverb: He lives on an island.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' when talking about islands, shores, beaches and coasts, when something is located on an island, shore, beach or coast (these are considered flat surfaces)

proverb: Lemurs are found only in Madagascar. Here we are talking about the country. Lemurs are found only on Madagascar. Here we are talking about the island.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place

proverb: Visiting Niagara Falls is a magical experience, especially for families.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with waterfalls

proverb: I hope one day humans will visit Saturn.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with planets. Don't forget that with our planet we can say 'Earth' or 'the Earth' interchangeably because it is a unique planet, one of a kind

proverb: It takes six to eight months to travel from Earth to Mars. The Earth rotates on its axis. The archaeologists excavated the earth at the site.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article with planets. Even though we don't use 'the' with planet names because they are proper nouns, when we are talking about our planet we often say 'the Earth', because it's a unique planet. When we are talking about the world in general we say 'on earth', for example 'everyone on earth has the right to education'. And lastly, when we are talking about the soft part of land (synonymous with dirt or soil) we say 'the earth'.

proverb: I love visiting Central Park.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of parks and squares

proverb: Times Square is a major commercial intersection in NYC.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of parks and squares

proverb: Red Square is the largest and most famous square in Russia.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of parks and squares

proverb: I use Twitter and Facebook every day.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of companies, brands, websites (these are considered proper nouns)

proverb: Bill Gates founded Microsoft.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of companies, brands, websites (these are considered proper nouns)

proverb: Walmart is the largest employer in the U.S.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of companies, brands, websites (these are considered proper nouns)

proverb: McDonald's has restaurants in 119 countries.
description: Usually the definite article is used with pubs, restaurants and hotels, but not when they are named after their owners/founders. McDonald's is a fast-food chain named after its founder. Another rule that can be applied here is that the definite article is not used with the names of companies (proper nouns)

proverb: She has a Ph.D. from MIT. But the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
description: We don't usually use 'the' with the names of schools, colleges, universities and university acronyms, unless they are named after a person, for example the John Hopkins University. Also, if the name of a school or university begins with 'school of' or 'university of', then we must use 'the': the Harvard School of Business, the College of the Holy Cross

proverb: Her son graduated from Harvard.
description: We don't usually use 'the' with the names of schools, colleges, universities and university acronyms, unless they are named after a person, for example the John Hopkins University. Also, if the name of a school or university begins with 'school of' or 'university of', then we must use 'the': the Harvard School of Business, the College of the Holy Cross

proverb: The universities of Oxford and Cambridge are two of the most famous universities in Europe.
description: We don't usually use 'the' with the names of schools, colleges, universities and university acronyms, unless they are named after a person, for example the John Hopkins University. Also, if the name of a school or university begins with 'school of' or 'university of', then we must use 'the': the Harvard School of Business, the College of the Holy Cross

proverb: Larry Page and Sergey Brin met at Stanford University where they studied for their PhD's in computer science.
description: We don't usually use 'the' with the names of schools, colleges, universities and university acronyms, unless they are named after a person, for example the John Hopkins University. Also, if the name of a school or university begins with 'school of' or 'university of', then we must use 'the': the Harvard School of Business, the College of the Holy Cross

proverb: In Brazil people speak Portuguese. The Japanese language is very complex.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article with languages. Usually we do not use the definite article with languages because the names of languages are proper nouns, but if an expression includes the word 'language', then it must be used:  the English language, the Russian language, etc

proverb: I have an appointment with doctor Smith tonight. I have an appointment with the doctor tonight.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article with titles without names and titles that also include names

proverb: The president has already signed a dozen executive orders. I have just called President Obama to congratulate him on his victory.
description: These sentences demonstrate the use of the definite article with titles without names and titles that also include names

proverb: Mother has returned.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with common names of relatives ('father', 'mother', 'son', 'daughter', 'brother', etc)

proverb: Is dad picking us up today?
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with common names of relatives ('father', 'mother', 'son', 'daughter', 'brother', etc)

proverb: Mom will cook an amazing dinner.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with common names of relatives ('father', 'mother', 'son', 'daughter', 'brother', etc). Also we do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is an occasion, like in this example.

proverb: Today we all went to the mall, and grandmother bought a new belt.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with common names of relatives ('father', 'mother', 'son', 'daughter', 'brother', etc)

proverb: I'll buy some bread at Smith's.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of shops. And it is a common practice to omit the following words: shop, bakery, grocery, pharmacy, etc especially if a place is named after someone. For example: Smith's Food & Drug or just Smith's, Nathan's Pharmacy or just Nathan's, Amy's Bakery or just Amy's, etc

proverb: They reached King's Cross at half past ten.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of stations

proverb: One of the Big Apple's most famous landmarks, Grand Central Terminal, officially opened in February 1913.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of stations and also demonstrates when to use the possessive 's

proverb: Buckingham Palace is where the Queen of England officially lives.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of churches, cathedrals and palaces

proverb: Cosmopolitan is an American monthly fashion and entertainment magazine for women.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of magazines

proverb: Lloyds Bank plc is a British retail and commercial bank with branches across England and Wales.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of banks

proverb: PrivatBank is the largest commercial bank in Ukraine, in terms of the number of clients, assets value, loan portfolio and taxes paid to the national budget.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of banks

proverb: I got a beautiful new dress for Christmas.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of holidays

proverb: We're going to meet on New Year's Day.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of holidays. New Year's Day is celebrated on January 1

proverb: What are you doing on Valentine's Day?
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of holidays

proverb: We're going to my parents for Easter.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of holidays

proverb: On the 31st of December, thousands of people gather in Times Square, New York, to celebrate the coming of the New Year.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of squares, and also with the names of holidays (we don't use 'the' with holidays but here we mean the whole next year, not the holiday). Also notice that the preposition of place 'in' is used with Times Square because squares and parks are considered enclosed spaces just like forests or gardens

proverb: My birthday is in September.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of the months and days of the week (these are proper nouns)

proverb: See you on Monday.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of the months and days of the week (these are proper nouns)

proverb: Tomorrow will be a hot day.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use any articles (definite or indefinite) before 'today', 'tomorrow' and 'yesterday' (these are uncout nouns)

proverb: Yesterday was our anniversary.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use any articles (definite or indefinite) before 'today', 'tomorrow' and 'yesterday' (these are uncout nouns)

proverb: Today is yesterday's tomorrow
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use any articles (definite or indefinite) before 'today', 'tomorrow' and 'yesterday' (these are uncout nouns). It also demonstrates when to use the possessive 's

proverb: We rarely get snow in winter. We rarely get snow in the winter.
description: These sentences demonstrate that when we talk about seasons in general, we can use either 'in' or 'in the'

proverb: The winter of 1947 was one of the coldest in Britain.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we need to use the definite article with seasons when we say 'the winter of' or 'the summer of'. Otherwise, when we talk about seasons in general, we can say either 'in winter' or 'in the winter'

proverb: I love to go skiing in the winter.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive, bare infinitive or gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'skiing' is the object of 'go'. 'go something' is often used to describe leisure activities that we do in our free time or do for fun: go running, go swimming, go hiking, go fishing, go kayaking, go berry picking, etc. 'go missing' is also a very common expression which means 'to become lost' or 'disappear'

proverb: Let's play volleyball!
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with sports and other physical activities

proverb: He loves watching hockey on TV.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with sports and other physical activities (hockey is an uncount noun: playing hockey, watching hockey). Also notice that the verb 'love' can be followed by either a gerund or an infinitive with no changing in meaning. We could say 'He loves to watch hockey ...' and it would mean the same

proverb: Of all the subjects taught in school, I like Geography best.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with subjects taught in school: Math, Geography, Business, History, Science (proper nouns). It also demonstrates the difference between 'best' and 'the best'. Here 'best' is an adverb, not an adjective, so the rule about needing the with superlatives does not apply here. 'best' and 'the best' as adverbs are both acceptable, but 'I like something best' is much more frequent than 'I like something the best'. Also notice that we say 'in school' when someone is a student studying at a school (or university), but not necessarily inside the school building at the moment.

proverb: Tom is really good at math.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with subjects taught in school: Math, Geography, Business, History, Science (proper nouns)

proverb: What would you like for breakfast?
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal, for example a formal occasion or a social event: They held a dinner to celebrate his retirement

proverb: What did you have for breakfast?
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal, for example a formal occasion or a social event: They held a dinner to celebrate his retirement

proverb: I ate way too much at dinner.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal. Here 'at' acts as a preposition of time and indicates the time when people eat dinner (за обедом)

proverb: I ate my dinner with a fork.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal. 'I ate dinner with a fork' is more appropriate to demonstrate this rule

proverb: Would you like to have dinner with me?
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal, for example a formal occasion or a social event: They held a dinner to celebrate his retirement

proverb: I can't talk now, I'm having dinner. Can you call back later?
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal. Also, the verb 'have' is used in the continuous form here and means 'experiencing' or 'taking', although it is usually used as a stative verb.

proverb: We organized a dinner for Dad's birthday.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal. Think of it as an event or occasion

proverb: We didn't like the dinner.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal. Think of it as an event or occasion

proverb: I am not hungry right now. I had a big breakfast.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal. Think of it as an event

proverb: I've never tried Korean food.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use 'the' with national cuisines. Here we are talking about Korean food in general, it is not something specific.

proverb: The train to Paris leaves from platform 2.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: Excuse me sir, can you tell me where I might find platform 9 3/4?
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: My English class is in room 6 on the first floor.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: See figures 1 and 2 on pages 3 and 4 for details.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: Man is mortal.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use articles (definite or indefinite) when a common noun is used in its widest sense. Actually, in this particular example 'man' is an uncountable noun and means the human race

proverb: What kind of bird is it?
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use articles (definite or indefinite) when a common noun is used in its widest sense

proverb: Man is the only animal that cooks food.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use articles (definite or indefinite) when a common noun is used in its widest sense. Actually, in this particular example 'man' is an uncountable noun and means the human race

proverb: Man proposes but God disposes.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use articles (definite or indefinite) when a common noun is used in its widest sense. Actually, in this particular example 'man' is an uncountable noun and means the human race (Человек предполагает, а Бог располагает)

proverb: There aren't many people who have read this novel to the end.
description: This sentence demonstrates which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. We tend to use 'many' and 'much' in questions and negatives, and use 'lots of' or 'a lot of' in affirmative statements.

proverb: Fewer people smoke these days than used to.
description: This sentence demonstrates which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. Also we use the following expression 'used to + infinitive' when we talk about habits or repeated actions in the past which we don't do anymore in the present. In this example it is not followed directly by an infinitive but the effect is the same

proverb: There were few people on the beach because it was raining.
description: This sentence demonstrates which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns, and also the difference between 'few' and 'a few'. Notice that 'on the beach' literally means the sand on the beach. 'at the beach' has a much broader scope

proverb: I have a number of things I want to talk to you about. He has a good job and makes a large amount of money.
description: These sentences demonstrate when to use 'number of' and when to use 'amount of' with count/uncount nouns

proverb: We need to go to the greengrocer's. There are few potatoes left.
description: This sentence demonstrates which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns, and also the difference between 'few' and 'a few'

proverb: No need to hurry! We still have a few hours left.
description: This sentence demonstrates which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns, and also the difference between 'few' and 'a few'

proverb: Our teacher gives us too much homework.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'too much' and 'too many'. We use 'too much' with uncout and 'too many' with count nouns in negative sentences, when we want to express that we don't like something

proverb: I've got a little money saved, I think I'll buy a new bike.
description: This sentence demonstrates which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And also it demonstrates the difference between 'a little' and 'little'

proverb: There's very little snow in the street. We don't need the snow boots.
description: These sentences demonstrate which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And we typically use 'on' with streets, roads, avenues when we mean somewhere on a street, but here we say 'in the street' because we mean the carriageway (проезжая часть) and it is an enclosed space (we use the preposition 'in' with enclosed spaces).

proverb: Hurry up! We have very little time left. Don't worry! We still have a little time left.
description: These sentences demonstrate which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And also it demonstrates the difference between 'a little' and 'little'

proverb: I have a number of things I want to talk to you about. The amount of time it took to finish the job was very frustrating.
description: These sentences demonstrate when to use 'number of' and when to use 'amount of' with count/uncount nouns

proverb: I speak a little English, so when I'm in England I don't have problems.
description: This sentence demonstrates which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And also it demonstrates the difference between 'a little' and 'little'. 'a little' implies that there's enough of something (positive statement)

proverb: The woman we met yesterday spoke little English and we couldn't really understand her.
description: This sentence demonstrates which quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And also it demonstrates the difference between 'a little' and 'little'

proverb: I went to the market and bought a lot of fruit.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we can use 'a lot of' with both count and uncount nouns. 'fruit' is usually uncountable.

proverb: Oh God, there's too many people!
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'too much' and 'too many'. We use 'too much' with uncout and 'too many' with count nouns in negative sentences, when we want to express that we don't like something. Also, it is grammatically incorrect to say 'there's too many', but it is widely used even among native speakers

proverb: I drank too much coffee, and now I feel sick. I drank a lot of beer, and now I feel good.
description: These sentences demonstrate when to use 'much', 'many' and 'a lot of'. We tend to use 'many' and 'much' in questions and negatives, and use 'lots of' or 'a lot of' in affirmative statements. Notice that the verb 'feel' can also be used in the continuous form without any change in meaning

proverb: I have a lot of friends. I have too many friends.
description: We tend to use 'many' and 'much' in questions and negative statements, and use 'lots of' or 'a lot of' in positive statements. The first sentence implies that you are happy, and the second sentence implies that you are unhappy

proverb: Time passes quickly. I had a nice time at the cinema.
description: These sentences demonstrate that the noun 'time' can be both count and non-count

proverb: There are times in life when people must know when not to let go.
description: This sentence demonstrates that the noun 'time' can be both count and non-count

proverb: How many times did I tell you?
description: This sentence demonstrates that the noun 'time' can be both count and non-count

proverb: My country does a lot of business with Argentina. My brother's self-employed, he owns a small business.
description: These sentences demonstrate that the noun 'business' can be both count and non-count

proverb: After dinner, I usually go for a walk in the wood near our house. I can't tell if this table is made of wood or plastic.
description: These two sentences demonstrate that the noun 'wood' can be both count and non-count. 'Dinner' is also a non-count noun.

proverb: All Sam's children have long, fair hair. Excuse me, waiter, but there's a hair in my soup.
description: These sentences demonstrate that the noun 'hair' can be both count and non-count

proverb: The train was scheduled to arrive on time at 13:36. Luckily we made it just in time!
description: These sentences demonstrate when to use 'on time' and when to use 'in time'

proverb: I didn't arrive at the cinema on time, but I still arrived in time to see the whole film.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'on time' and when to use 'in time'. It also demonstrates that the verb 'arrive' indicates location or time, but not movement, so we use the usual prepositions of place or time after it. We always say 'arrived at the cinema', not 'arrived to the cinema'

proverb: You mean to tell me you have never ridden a horse before?
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'ride'. We ride something if we are on top of it (верхом): ride a bicycle, horse, bike, tiger, etc. And we don't generally use 'on' after 'ride': ride on a horse, ride on a bike, although it is acceptable. If the rider is holding the reins, he/she is riding the horse. If, however, someone is sitting behind the rider, that person is riding on a horse. Also note that 'mean' is a stative verb

proverb: The West End is easy to reach by Tube.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions

proverb: The quickest way to get there is by air.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions

proverb: I will contact you by email. I will contact you by phone.
description: The preposition 'by' is usually followed by a verb but sometimes it is followed by a noun in certain situation, for example when we're talking about how we communicate. It is also often used when talking about trasportation, for example: Our children go to school by bus. Notice that there is no article after 'by'

proverb: Today is a brand new day.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions before Today, Tomorrow or Yesterday because these are uncountable nouns

proverb: The air is so clean at sunrise.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime, etc).

proverb: I'll be asleep at midnight!
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dinner, etc). 'at night' is an exception and needs to be memorized.

proverb: I'll be there at dawn.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime).

proverb: I'll go shopping at lunchtime.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'at lunchtime', 'at dinnertime', at 'suppertime', 'at dinner', 'at breakfast', etc when we mean the time when people have a meal, not the meal itself - за обедом, во время обеда

proverb: I ate too much at dinner.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'at lunchtime', 'at dinnertime', at 'suppertime', 'at dinner', 'at breakfast', etc when we mean the time when people have a meal, not the meal itself - за ужином, во время ужина

proverb: At breakfast, he didn't say a word, just read his newspaper.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'at lunchtime', 'at dinnertime', at 'suppertime', 'at dinner', 'at breakfast', etc when we mean the time when people have a meal, not the meal itself - за завтраком, во время завтрака

proverb: I read my daughter a story at bedtime.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime).

proverb: He wrote this book at the age of twenty.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times within one day (twenty-four hours to be precise): at 3pm, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime, etc. But 'at' is also often used when talking about someone's age. It is most often used when talking about the past, and sometimes the future: I started driving at 16(I started driving when I was 16), I will be a millionaire at 40

proverb: He doesn't like driving at night.
description: The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dinner, etc). 'at night' is an exception and needs to be memorized.

proverb: We went for a walk along the beach at twilight.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime).

proverb: We are visiting friends and relatives at Christmas. We'll be opening our gifts on Christmas Day.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In the first sentece we mean the whole holiday period (several days). In the second - only one day

proverb: Did you have a good time at Easter? What will you be doing on Easter Sunday?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In the first sentece we mean the whole holiday period (several days). In the second - only one day

proverb: What are you doing on New Year's Day? What are you doing at New Year's?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In the first sentece we mean only one day, January 1. In the second - the whole holiday period (few days around that time in general - в новогодние праздники). We can also say on New Year's Eve and it also means one day - December 31

proverb: I like staying at home and watching movies on New Year's Day. I like going to big parties on New Year's. What are you doing at New Year's?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In the first sentece we mean one day, January 1. In the second we also mean one day - December 31. On New Year's implies New Year's Eve, as a shortcut for referring to December 31. And in the third sentence we mean the whole holiday period (few days around that time in general - новогодние праздники)

proverb: Let's have a coffee on Friday morning. Where did you go on Thursday night? I'm usually available on Monday and Friday afternoons.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. We use the preposition 'on' with days and dates, but also with parts of a day

proverb: I'm going to go shopping on the weekend. What are you doing on the weekend? What did you do on the weekend?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. Weekend means a period of time somewhere between Friday evening and Sunday night. In American English we use 'on' with weekends, in British English we use 'at'. Weekend is mostly used in singular form (always preceded with 'the') and can mean either a specific weekend (previous or upcoming) or any weekend. But remember that 'the' is not used when talking about last weekend (прошлые выходные) or next weekned (следующие выходные), for example: She cleaned the room last weekend.  Weekend can also be used in its plural form (on weekends or on the weekends can be used interchangeably) when we're talking about something habitual

proverb: We go out once in a while on the weekends. We go out once in a while on weekends.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. Weekend means a period of time somewhere between Friday evening and Sunday night. In American English we use 'on' with weekends, in British English we use 'at'. Weekend is mostly used in singular form (always preceded with 'the') and can mean either a specific weekend (previous or upcoming) or any weekend. But remember that 'the' is not used when talking about last weekend (прошлые выходные) or next weekned (следующие выходные), for example: She cleaned the room last weekend. Weekend can also be used in its plural form (on weekends or  on the weekends can be used interchangeably) when we're talking about something habitual

proverb: They usually go windsurfing on the weekends. They usually go windsurfing on weekends.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. Weekend means a period of time somewhere between Friday evening and Sunday night. In American English we use 'on' with weekends, in British English we use 'at'. Weekend is mostly used in singular form (always preceded with 'the') and can mean either a specific weekend (previous or upcoming) or any weekend. But remember that 'the' is not used when talking about last weekend (прошлые выходные) or next weekned (следующие выходные), for example: She cleaned the room last weekend. Weekend can also be used in its plural form (on weekends or  on the weekends can be used interchangeably) when we're talking about something habitual

proverb: On the weekends, I like to watch football. On weekends, I like to watch football.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. Weekend means a period of time somewhere between Friday evening and Sunday night. In American English we use 'on' with weekends, in British English we use 'at'. Weekend is mostly used in singular form (always preceded with 'the') and can mean either a specific weekend (previous or upcoming) or any weekend. But remember that 'the' is not used when talking about last weekend (прошлые выходные) or next weekned (следующие выходные), for example: She cleaned the room last weekend. It can also be used in its plural form (on weekends or  on the weekends can be used interchangeably) when we're talking about something habitual

proverb: The kids have been on vacation two weeks.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time (or place???). We say 'on vacation', 'on holiday', 'on a cruise', 'on a trip', 'on a picnic' and 'on an adventure'. The word 'vacation - каникулы, отпуск' refers to your personal time off from work or school – usually an extended time, not just one day, and vacations often involve traveling. The word 'holiday - праздник' is used for important days that are celebrated by a lot of people. Holidays are celebrated usually by your whole country or whole culture.

proverb: When I was on holiday in Cancun I caught swine fever.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'on vacation', 'on holiday', 'on a cruise', 'on a trip', 'on a picnic' and 'on an adventure'. The word 'vacation - каникулы, отпуск' refers to your personal time off from work or school – usually an extended time, not just one day, and vacations often involve traveling. The word 'holiday - праздник' is used for important days that are celebrated by a lot of people. Holidays are celebrated usually by your whole country or whole culture. But here's where it gets tricky – when you're in the middle of a vacation, American English speakers say you are on vacation, and British English speakers say you are on holiday. Also most long term diseases are not countable

proverb: The printing press was invented in the Middle Ages.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the preposition 'in' with months, seasons, years, centuries and other long periods. We also need to use the definite article when talking about centuries, decades and historic periods

proverb: It's too hot to go out in the middle of the day.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We always say 'in the middle of some period of time': in the middle of the year, in the middle of the week, in the middle of the month

proverb: You can drive around the island in a day.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <a period of time>' when we need to specify a certain amount of time required to do something: in an hour, in a day, in two weeks, etc

proverb: I haven't seen her in years.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <a period of time>' when we need to emphasize the length of time that has passed since a past event: in hours, in days, in two weeks, in years, etc

proverb: I'll meet you in an hour.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <a period of time>' when we need to explain when something will happen in the future: in a day, in two weeks, in a month, etc

proverb: I'll be ready in 5 minutes.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <a period of time>' when we need to explain when something will happen in the future: in a day, in two weeks, in a month, etc

proverb: He's gone away but he'll be back in a couple of days.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <period of time>' when we need to explain when something will happen in the future: in a day, in two weeks, in a month, etc

proverb: We have class in two hours.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <period of time>' when we need to explain when something will happen in the future: in a day, in two weeks, in a month, etc. It also demonstrates that the noun 'class' has two meanings: a period of time in which students are taught something, or a group of students who are taught together. In this example class means a period of time, can be translated into Russian as 'урок'

proverb: I woke up early in the morning. I'm going to the library in the evening. Does she sleep in the afternoon?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. Although the preposition 'at' is generally used in reference to specific points of time in the day (at 3 pm, at noon, at midnight, at dinner), we always say 'in the morning' or 'in the evening'. These indications of time are exceptions and need to be memorized

proverb: Luckily we arrived just in time, we still have 5 minutes!
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'on time' and when to use 'in time'

proverb: The show should be finished by 9 p.m. Please, return these books by Friday.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. The preposition 'by' is used to indicate the end time of an activity, meaning 'no later than'

proverb: We need to be there by noon. I will be at the restaurant by 8 pm.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. The preposition 'by' is used to indicate the end time of an activity, meaning 'no later than' (к полудню, к 8 часам)

proverb: This animal always hunts by night.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition 'by' is used to indicate the end time of an activity, meaning 'no later than'. For example: 'We need to be there by noon'. But this is an exception to the rule. 'By night' means по ночам

proverb: I will be at the restaurant by 8 pm. I will be at the restaurant until 8 pm.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. These two sentences have two different meanings depending on which preposition is used

proverb: Are you nervous about singing in front of your parents tonight?
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words such as 'tonight/next/this/last/every/recently/etc'. Also notice that the preposition 'about' is followed by the gerund. In English all prepositions must be followed by the gerund.

proverb: I was waiting for you all day.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words, specifically 'all': all day, all night, all morning, all year, etc

proverb: The train leaves tomorrow morning. I have a test tomorrow morning.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words, specifically when we say 'tomorrow + part of day' or 'yesterday + part of day'

proverb: She was in the hospital the day before yesterday. We're flying to Mexico the day after tomorrow.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. 'The day before yesterday' and 'the day after tomorrow' are set expressions that don't require any additional prepositions. Also notice that 'she was in the hospital' means she was a patient receiving care or treatment, not just visiting the hospital.

proverb: I took him to the bus station yesterday evening.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words, specifically with 'tomorrow' and 'yesterday' and also when we say 'tomorrow + part of day' or 'yesterday + part of day'

proverb: Recently, my eyes have been bothering me.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words such as 'all day/tonight/next/this/last/every/recently/etc'. Also we often use 'recently' with the present perfect or the present perfect continuous to talk about past recent actions

proverb: We signed the deal a week ago. I'm not sure where I'll be a year from now.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. 'a week ago', 'a month ago', 'a year from now' are set expressions that don't require any additional prepositions

proverb: We told him about it the following day. The weeks following the riots were extremely tense.
description: These two sentences demonstate the difference between 'the following' and 'following'. When we say 'the following + (day, month, year, etc)', it's an adjective and means 'next' (на следующий, в следующем). It describes the noun that comes after it: day, week, month, etc. 'the following day' can be viewed as a whole unit. In the second sentence 'following' is a preposition and means 'after' (после, последовавший за)

proverb: They arranged to have dinner the following month. Following the dinner, there will be a dance.
description: These two sentences demonstate the difference between 'the following' and 'following'. When we say 'the following + (day, month, year, etc)', it's an adjective and means 'next' (на следующий, в следующем). It describes the noun that comes after it: day, week, month, etc. 'the following month' can be viewed as a whole unit. In the second sentence 'following' is a preposition and means 'after' (после, последовавший за)

proverb: Wear a sweater but carry a gun
description: This sentence demonstrates when we use the verb 'wear' and when we use the verb 'carry'

proverb: She is wearing a ring on her finger.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'wear' (wear is used with clothes, jewelry, watches, glasses, makeup and perfume), and we use it in the continuous form when we want to describe the action of wearing something, because it is something that is taking place over time or was taking place over time: 'She was wearing...'. The simple form is usually used to express a habitual action. Compare: 'The girl is wearing a black dress' means she is wearing it at the moment, 'The girl wears a black dress every time she goes to church' means on a regular basis but not necessarily at the moment. It also demonstrates when to use the preposition 'on' (when something is attached to something else)

proverb: I used to wear too much makeup, but not anymore.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'wear' (wear is used with clothes, jewelry, watches, glasses, makeup and perfume)

proverb: She helped me to carry my suitcases.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'carry' (когда что-то несется в руке или в руках, в кармане). It is also very common to hear the phrase 'to carry a child' which means to be pregnant (to be with child): 'She is carrying my child - она вынашивает моего ребенка, она беременна моим ребенком'

proverb: Your body is not ready to carry a baby. She is carrying my child.
description: The most common use of the verb 'carry' is to hold something or someone with your hands, arms, or on your back and transport it. It is also very common to hear the phrase 'to carry a child' which means to be pregnant/to be with child: 'She is carrying my child - она вынашивает моего ребенка, она беременна моим ребенком'. It is used in the continuous form because it is something that is taking place over time (very similar to 'wear'). It can also be interpreted literally, for example: 'The dad was carrying the child, and his wife was next to him when they were crossing the street.'

proverb: The police in Britain, the Irish Republic and New Zealand don't usually carry guns.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'carry' (когда что-то несется в руке или в руках, в кармане). It also demonstrates that 'police' is normally a plural, collective noun, so we always say 'The police are', but it can be followed by singular verbs when it is thought of as a single unit (The police force, the Police Department)

proverb: I always carry it in my pocket.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'carry' (когда что-то несется в руке или в руках, в кармане). It is also very common to hear the phrase 'to carry a child' which means to be pregnant (to be with child): 'She is carrying my child - она вынашивает моего ребенка, она беременна моим ребенком'

proverb: How much money did you make last year? How much money have you made this year?
description: This sentence demonstrates the difference between the past simple and the present perfect. And also when to use 'last' or 'the last'

proverb: We all have our cross to bear.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'bear' (нести груз, нести тяжесть, нести на себе, вынести, вынашивать, терпеть)

proverb: I'm at John's house. I had a coffee at Helen's house. He is at his aunt's.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with specific places, public places, shops, hotels, homes etc. We often say: I am at John's or she is at her aunt's (the implication is John's house or aunt's house)

proverb: My friend works at the hospital downtown.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place.
