Specifically, we say 'at the hospital' when we mean somebody just visiting the hospital (being on the premises of the hospital), but not as a patient. We say 'in the hospital' when we mean somebody being an in-patient at the hospital. However, in certain circumstances 'in the hospital' could mean literally inside the hospital building: 'Sam was in the hospital when it caught fire.'

proverb: He was so sick he spent a week in the hospital.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, we say 'at the hospital' when we mean somebody just visiting the hospital (being on the premises of the hospital), but not as a patient. We say 'in the hospital' when we mean somebody being an in-patient at the hospital. However, in certain circumstances 'in the hospital' could mean literally inside the hospital building: 'Sam was in the hospital when it caught fire.'

proverb: Jack had an accident last week. He was taken to the hospital. He is still in the hospital now. Jill has gone to the hospital to visit Jack. She is at the hospital now.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, we say 'at the hospital' when we mean somebody just visiting the hospital (being on the premises of the hospital), but not as a patient. We say 'in the hospital' when we mean somebody being an in-patient at the hospital. However, in certain circumstances 'in the hospital' could mean literally inside the hospital building: 'Sam was in the hospital when it caught fire.'

proverb: I am at the movie theater.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with specific places, public places, shops, hotels, homes, theaters, places of work, etc

proverb: He works at Burger King on Bay Street.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with specific places, public places, shops, hotels, homes, theaters, places of work, etc. Notice that there is no 'the' before Burger King because it is a proper noun, the name of the street is also a proper noun.

proverb: They are sitting at the table. They are sitting on the table.
description: These sentences explain prepositions of place.

proverb: We arrived at the airport. I'm arriving in London tomorrow. The movie will be over by the time we arrive at the theater.
description: These sentences demonstrate what prepositions to use with the verb 'arrive'. 'arrive' is a verb that indicates location or time, but not movement, so we use the usual prepositions of place or time after it (or no prepositions, for example: arrive home, arrive yesterday, arrive next week).

proverb: We arrived home yesterday.
description: This sentence demonstrates what prepositions to use with the verb 'arrive'. 'arrive' is a verb that indicates location or time, but not movement, so we use the usual prepositions of place or time after it (or no prepositions, for example: arrive home, arrive yesterday, arrive next week).

proverb: I'll be arriving on Friday and leaving the following Thursday.
description: This sentence demonstrates what prepositions to use with the verb 'arrive'. 'arrive' is a verb that indicates location or time, but not movement, so we use the usual prepositions of place or time after it (or no prepositions, for example: arrive home, arrive yesterday, arrive next week).

proverb: He was sitting at the top of the stairs.
description: This sentence explains how to use prepositions of place. We always say 'at the top of', or 'at the bottom of' something

proverb: The museum is at the end of the street. The car was stopped in the middle of the street.
description: This sentence explains how to use prepositions of place. We always say 'at the end of', 'at the center of', 'at the beginning of', 'at the back of', etc, but 'in the middle'

proverb: He was crying at the back of the classroom.
description: This sentence explains how to use prepositions of place. We always say 'at the end of', 'at the center of', 'at the back of', 'at the beginning of'

proverb: I'll meet you at the corner of Beach Street and Park Road. The supermarket is on the corner of Martin Street. I saw it in the corner of the room.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, 'at the corner' means near or adjacent to a corner, can also be used to refer to the corner when two streets intersect each other. We use 'on the corner' when the corner is outside, usually when something is located on the corner, for example a building or shop. And we use 'in the corner' when the corner is inside

proverb: He will meet us at the corner of the street. This shop is on the corner of High Street. I saw it in the corner of the room.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, 'at the corner' means near or adjacent to a corner, can also be used to refer to the corner when two streets intersect each other. We use 'on the corner' when the corner is outside, usually when something is located on the corner, for example a building or shop. And we use 'in the corner' when the corner is inside

proverb: We met at a party. We met at a wedding.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with events

proverb: He's speaking at the conference later this week. I don't want to see her at the party tonight.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with events

proverb: I live on Hill Road. Don't walk in the street, it's dangerous! Walk here on the sidewalk. I am at Fifth Avenue and 43rd Street.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Typically, we use the preposition 'on' with streets, roads, avenues when we mean somewhere on a street, but not specific address. 'in the street' literally means the carriageway (проезжая часть), it is considered an enclosed space, that's why the preposition 'in' is used. The last sentence means specific address where two streets intersect.

proverb: You have something on your face.
description: This sentence explains prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with flat or spherical surfaces (floor, shelf, table, wall, map, page, Earth, moon, etc)

proverb: The poem is on page 44.
description: This sentence explains prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with flat or spherical surfaces (floor, shelf, table, wall, map, page, Earth, moon, etc). But remember that when we're talking about a whole book we need to use the preposition 'in'. When we talk about information represented on paper, we say 'in a book, newspaper, magazine, letter', but 'on a page'. Also, we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: She said she wouldn't marry him if he were the last man on Earth.
description: This is an example of the second conditional. The second conditional is used to imagine present or future situations that are impossible or unlikely in reality. This sentence is also an example of reported speech. Reported speech is when we talk about something that someone else has said.

proverb: There are over 7 billion people on earth.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with flat or spherical surfaces (floor, shelf, table, wall, map, page, Earth, moon, etc). Here 'on earth' means 'in the world' not the planet Earth. It also demonstrates when to use the preposition 'over'

proverb: The first man walked on the Moon in 1969.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with flat or spherical surfaces (floor, shelf, table, wall, map, page, Earth, moon, etc). And we always say 'the Moon' or 'the moon' when talking about the moon that revolves around the Earth because it is our only satellite. But with other planets, for example Jupiter or Saturn, which have multiple moons, one particular satellite can be called a moon.

proverb: I grew up on a farm in Manitoba. The straw may be burned on the farm to provide heat or electricity.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We always say 'on the farm' or 'on a farm'

proverb: I'm on your side! The museum is on the south side of the city.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We always use the preposition 'on' with 'side' (side is a flat surface)

proverb: The boy on the left is the shortest. Move a little to the left, please.
description: These sentences demonstrate the difference between 'on the left' and 'to the left'. 'on the left' means 'слева', it implies location, to be more precise, it implies the left side, that's why it is used with the preposition of place 'on'. We could say: The boy on the left side is the shortest. 'to the left' means 'налево', it implies direction, that's why it is used with the preposition of movement/direction 'to'

proverb: There are three apples on the tree.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' when something is attached to something else

proverb: I like the smile on her face.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' when something is attached to something else

proverb: What's that on the water?
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with bodies of water: oceans, rivers and lakes (these are also considered flat surfaces). Specifically, in this sentence we mean that something is on the surface of a lake or a river.

proverb: We'll take you out on the lake. We want to have a picnic at the lake. Lots of people were swimming in the lake.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place when talking about bodies of water. In the first sentence we mean the surface of the lake (for example lake boating). The second sentence means having a picnic at the beach (not on the water). We can also say: We want to have a picnic by the lake. The third sentence uses 'in' because people are submerged in water, and not necessarily on the surface

proverb: London is on the river Thames. He has a house on the river.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place when talking about bodies of water. The preposition 'on' is used when something is located on the shore of that body of water. Other examples: I have a beautiful house on the sea.

proverb: I shouldn't have said that!
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use the modal verb 'should' when expressing hindsight advice / regrets

proverb: The farm was used to produce produce.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to pronounce 'produce' as a noun and as a verb in American English

proverb: Do people live on Tasmania island? He lives in Tasmania.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' when talking about islands, shores, beaches and coasts (these are considered flat surfaces). We use the preposition 'in' when talking about large enclosed geographical areas (cities, countries, states, provinces, the world, etc). In the first sentence we mean the island, and in the second sentence we mean the state (Tasmania is one of Australia's states)

proverb: Nice is on the south coast of France. Nice is in the south of France.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' when talking about islands, shores, beaches and coasts (these are considered flat surfaces) and their geographical parts. In the first sentence 'south' is an adjective. We use the preposition 'in' when talking about large enclosed geographical areas (cities, countries, the world, etc) and their parts. In the second sentence 'south' is a noun.

proverb: Niagara Falls is located on the border between the United States and Canada.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We always say that something 'is on the border'. It also demonstrates the use of the definite article with countries and waterfalls

proverb: He was speaking on the phone.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with electronic devices. Maybe because the screen of an electronic device has a flat surface (display)

proverb: I was working on my computer.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with electronic devices. Maybe because the screen of an electronic device has a flat surface (display)

proverb: I heard it on the radio.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with electronic devices (when information is represented on electronic devices, but we say 'listen to the radio')

proverb: You have too many pictures on your phone.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with electronic devices (when information is represented on electronic devices). Maybe because the screen of an electronic device has a flat surface (display). It also demonstrates that  We use 'too much' with uncout and 'too many' with count nouns in negative sentences, when we want to express that we don't like something

proverb: My favorite show is on TV. What's on TV tonight? Have you ever been on TV?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with electronic devices (when information is represented on electronic devices). Maybe because the screen of an electronic device has a flat surface (display)

proverb: Do not go on the Internet.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place and also when to use the definite article. We use the preposition 'on' with the Internet / websites (but not with email). And we always say 'the Internet' because it is a unique thing (one of a kind)

proverb: You'll find more information on our website.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with the Internet / websites (but not with email)

proverb: Don't worry if you missed the concert! I'm sure someone must have uploaded it on YouTube.
description: This example demonstrates how to use prepositions of place and also when to use the definite article. We use the preposition 'on' with the Internet / websites (but not with email). And we do not use the definite article with the names of companies, brands, websites (these are considered proper nouns). It also demonstrates that we use the modal verb 'must' for logical conclusion or strong deduction (должно быть) where we are 90% certain of something

proverb: She has many friends on Facebook.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place and also when to use the definite article. We use the preposition 'on' with the Internet / websites (but not with email). And we do not use the definite article with the names of companies, brands, websites (these are considered proper nouns)

proverb: The teacher wrote her name up on the board. She started in the firm by making the tea and now she's on the board. Welcome on board!
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. In the first sentence 'board' means a blackboard and it is a flat surface, that's why we use the preposition 'on'. In the second sentence 'board' means a high-level group of people where members are elected or hired (and can be thought of as some kind of platform). The last sentence is used literally when welcoming someone to board a public vehicle, which is also considered a platform: plane, train, ship, or bus, etc, or figuratively when welcoming a new member of a team

proverb: She has served on the committee for the last fifteen years.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with high-level groups of people where members are often elected (board, committee, jury, council, etc). Think of it as some kind of platform.

proverb: She was selected to sit on a jury.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with high-level groups of people where members are often elected (board, committee, jury, council, etc). Think of it as some kind of platform.

proverb: The dump was so full that it had to refuse more refuse.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to pronounce the word 'refuse' as a verb and as a noun

proverb: Is your name on the list?
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' in the following expressions: 'on the list', 'on the menu', 'on the team'

proverb: There is no meat on the menu tonight.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' in the following expressions: 'on the list', 'on the menu', 'on the team'

proverb: He is by far the best player on the team. He's got selected to play in the national team.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'on the team' and 'in the team'. 'On the team' is mostly used in American English and basically means the same as being on the list. We can also say 'in the team' when we mean the actual group of people

proverb: He is by far the best player on the team. She works in the finance team.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'on the team' and 'in the team'. 'On the team' is mostly used in American English and basically means the same as being on the list. We can also say 'in the team' when we mean the actual group of people

proverb: He has never been the same since.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the Present Perfect Tense. We usually use the Present Perfect Continuous for something that started in the past and still continues in the present, but the verb 'be' is a stative verb in this context and can't be used with continuous tenses, that's why the PP is used. Another thing that indicates that the PP tense must be used is that this sentence includes the word 'never' which indicates an unfinished period of time. Similar examples: I've known him for years (and I still know him). Sam has had this car since 2012 (Sam still has his car).

proverb: Get on the bus! Get off the bus!
description: These expressions demonstrate how to use transportation prepositions. Use the prepositions 'in/out' when something/someone is inside a small vehicle (car, taxi, truck). Use 'on/off' with vehicles considered a platform and also public transportation (bus, train, plane, boat, subway), or when you ride something (bike, horse, etc)

proverb: Get on the train! Get off the train!
description: These expressions demonstrate how to use transportation prepositions. Use the prepositions 'in/out' when something/someone is inside a small vehicle (car, taxi, truck). Use 'on/off' with vehicles considered a platform and also public transportation (bus, train, plane, boat, subway), or when you ride something (bike, horse, etc)

proverb: There were three hundred people on board the ship.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions. Use the prepositions 'in/out' when something/someone is inside a small vehicle (car, taxi, truck). Use 'on/off' with vehicles considered a platform and also public transportation (bus, train, plane, boat, subway), or when you ride something (bike, horse, etc)

proverb: Welcome to rush hour on the Tube.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions. Use the prepositions 'in/out' when something/someone is inside a small vehicle (car, taxi, truck). Use 'on/off' with vehicles considered a platform and also public transportation (bus, train, plane, boat, subway), or when you ride something (motorcycle, horse, etc)

proverb: He likes riding his horse.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with means of transportation which are considered a platform (bus, train, ship, etc) and also when we ride something (bicycle, horse, motorcycle), we can ride something if we are on top of it. But we don't generally use 'on' after 'ride': ride on a horse, ride on a bike, although it is acceptable. If the rider is holding the reins, he/she is riding the horse. If, however, someone is sitting behind the rider, that person is riding on a horse.

proverb: You get on a train, bus, or subway to begin your trip.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions. Use the prepositions 'in/out' when something/someone is inside a small vehicle (car, taxi, truck). Use 'on/off' with vehicles considered a platform and also public transportation (bus, train, plane, boat, subway), or when you ride something (motorcycle, horse, etc)

proverb: Which flight is she traveling on?
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions. Use the prepositions 'in/out' when something/someone is inside a small vehicle (car, taxi, truck). Use 'on/off' with vehicles considered a platform and also public transportation (bus, train, plane, boat, subway), or when you ride something (motorcycle, horse, etc)

proverb: Get on the horse! Get off the horse!
description: These expressions demonstrate how to use transportation prepositions. We use the preposition 'on' with means of transportation which are considered a platform (bus, train, ship, etc) and also when we ride something (bicycle, horse, motorcycle), we can ride something if we are on top of it

proverb: These pots are on sale for $20.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We always say that something is 'on sale', it's a set expression

proverb: I bought these pants on sale for half price.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We always say that something is 'on sale', it's a set expression

proverb: I live in a house.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' when talking about being inside a building, room, house, etc (enclosed spaces)

proverb: I like to study in my bedroom.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' when talking about being inside a building, room, house, etc (enclosed spaces)

proverb: I went to see this movie while I was still in high school.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We say 'in school' when we mean studying in general but not necessarily being inside the school building at that moment. 'at school' means the person is literally, physically, inside the school. 'school' can also mean a building where children/adults receive education

proverb: John is having trouble at school. Has John graduated yet? No, he's still in school.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, 'at school' means the person is literally, physically, inside the school studying. 'in school' means the person is studying in general but not necessarily inside the school building at that moment. 'school' can also mean a building where children/adults receive education

proverb: Hi, is David home at the moment? No, he's at school, he should be home by 5 pm. My husband doesn't have a job because he's in school. He's studying law.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, 'at school' means the person is literally, physically, inside the school studying. 'in school' means the person is studying in general but not necessarily inside the school building at that moment. 'school' can also mean a building where children/adults receive education

proverb: My friend works at the hospital downtown. Unfortunately, Mr Brown is in the hospital. He broke his leg.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, we say 'at the hospital' when we mean somebody just visiting the hospital or working there (being on the premises of the hospital), but not as a patient. We say 'in the hospital' when we mean somebody being an in-patient at the hospital. However, in certain circumstances 'in the hospital' could mean literally inside the hospital building: 'Sam was in the hospital when it caught fire.'

proverb: I've got the key in my pocket. There's nothing left in my cup. There's some milk in the fridge.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with enclosed spaces

proverb: David is playing in the forest. David is playing in the garden.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with enclosed spaces. Forests, gardens, parks and squares are considered enclosed spaces

proverb: There is always lots of action in Times Square.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with enclosed spaces (squares and parks are considered enclosed spaces just like forests or gardens). It also demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of parks and squares

proverb: Hiking in the mountains is a popular activity.
description: When we talk about mountains in broad terms (горная местность, горы в широком смысле), we say 'the mountains'. Similar examples: I've never been to the sea (Я никогда не был на море), I prefer to live in the country instead of the town (Я предпочитаю жить в сельской местности чем в городе). These are set expressions

proverb: Would you prefer to live in the country instead of a town?
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with enclosed spaces ('in the country' is a set expression which means 'в сельской местности'). And we can use either a gerund or an infinitive after 'like', 'love', 'hate', 'prefer', but we use only an infinitive after 'would like', 'would love', 'would hate', 'would prefer'. Also notice that 'like', 'love', 'hate' and 'prefer' are stative verbs

proverb: Don't keep this medicine in the sun.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. 'in the sun' means in the sunlight (на свету, на солнечном свете)

proverb: The kids were in the sun all day, and they got sunburned. Helium was detected on the sun before it was ever found on the Earth.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'in the sun' and 'on the sun'. 'in the sun' means in the sunlight (на свету, на солнечном свете), 'on the sun' literally means on the surface of the Sun (our star)

proverb: Don't stay in the sun too long. She called me every name under the sun.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'in the sun' and 'under the sun'. 'in the sun' means in the sunlight (на свету, на солнечном свете). 'under the sun' means in existence (в целом мире, на целом свете), it is an idiomatic expression that emphasizes that there is a large number of something, as many as you can imagine

proverb: I put the plants in the sun to help them grow. There is nothing under the sun that we cannot do.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'in the sun' and 'under the sun'. 'in the sun' means in the sunlight (на свету, на солнечном свете). 'Under the sun' means in existence (в целом мире, на целом свете), it is an idiomatic expression that emphasizes that there is a large number of something, as many as you can imagine. We can also say 'on the sun' when we mean the surface of the Sun (the star)

proverb: There were no clouds in the sky.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with the sky. It also demonstrates the use of the definite article, we always say 'the sky' because it is a unique thing

proverb: We can see thousands of stars in the sky.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with the sky. It also demonstrates the use of the definite article, we always say 'the sky' because it is a unique thing

proverb: Central Park is an urban park in New York City.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with large geographical areas (cities, countries, deserts, the world), these are considered enclosed spaces. It also demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of parks and squares

proverb: Camels are often used to travel in the desert.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with large geographical areas (cities, countries, deserts, the world), these are considered enclosed spaces. It also demonstrates that we need to use the definite article with the names of deserts (the Sahara Desert, the Gobi Desert), but notice that here we are not talking about a particular desert, we are talking about deserts in general (similar to 'in the mountains, in the country')

proverb: I live in Canada. I live in the west of the city. Egypt is in the north of Africa.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with large geographical areas and their parts (cities, countries, deserts, the world), these are considered enclosed spaces. It also demonstrates the use of the definite article when referring to the West, North, East or South as geographical parts of something. In the second and third sentences 'west' and 'north' are nouns.

proverb: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'in' with large geographical areas and their parts (cities, countries, deserts, the world). We also use the definine article when referring to the West, North, East or South as geographical parts of something, but when we refer to the West, East, North or South as directions we don't use the definite article: 'I am traveling north'

proverb: I left my phone in the car. I left my phone on the bus.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use transportation prepositions. Use the preposition 'in' when something/someone is inside a small vehicle (car, taxi, truck). Use 'on' with vehicles considered a platform and also public transportation (bus, train, plane, boat, subway) or when you ride something (motorcycle, horse, etc)

proverb: Get in the car! Get out of the car!
description: These expressions demonstrate how to use transportation prepositions. Use the prepositions 'in/out' when something/someone is inside a small vehicle (car, taxi, truck). Use 'on/off' with vehicles considered a platform and also public transportation (bus, train, plane, boat, subway) or when you ride something (motorcycle, horse)

proverb: The author makes that point repeatedly in his novel.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. Use the preposition 'in' with information represented on paper (book, letter, newspaper, magazine). We write or draw on some surface (paper), but read in a book or newspaper.

proverb: Have you read our professor's latest article in The New York Times? Have you read our professor's latest article on The New York Times website?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Use the preposition 'in' with information represented on paper (book, letter, newspaper, magazine) and also email. Use the preposition 'on' with information represented on electronic devices and also on The Internet and websites (but not email). It also demonstrates that we use the definite article with newspaper names

proverb: All the stories in the book are very special. Can you write it on that piece of paper?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Use the preposition 'in' with information represented on paper (book, letter, newspaper, magazine). We write or draw on some surface (paper), but read in a book or newspaper.

proverb: Who is that person next to you in the picture? There is some dirt on the picture of our dog.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We say 'in the picture / photograph / drawing' when something is a part of the visual image of the picture. We say 'on the picture' when something is physically different from the picture that is somehow connected or attached to the picture such as dust, a coffee cup, etc

proverb: The boy in the photo looks sad. There's a cup on a photo.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We say 'in the picture / photograph / drawing' when something is a part of the visual image of the picture. We say 'on the picture' when something is physically different from the picture that is somehow connected or attached to the picture such as dust, a coffee cup, etc

proverb: I will send you the 2nd part in my next email.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. Use the preposition 'in' with information represented on paper (book, letter, newspaper, magazine) and also email. Use the preposition 'on' with information represented on electronic devices and also on The Internet and websites (but not email). Because an email is regarded as a letter, even though it is viewed on an electronic device)

proverb: You shouldn't have thrown the gun down the toilet, Eva!
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use modal verbs. We use the modal verb should + have + p.p for past (hindsight) advice or regrets

proverb: There's too much sugar in soft drinks.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. Use the preposition 'in' with liquids and other substances to show what they contain. It also demonstrates when to use 'too much'. We use 'too much' with uncountable nouns in negative sentences, when we want to express that we don't like something.

proverb: He lives in a tiny cottage in the middle of nowhere.

proverb: Someone phoned when I was in the middle of bathing the baby.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We always say 'in the middle' of something

proverb: He's waiting by the car.

proverb: Put your bag by the door and sit down.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'by' means next to something or beside something (Положи свою сумку у двери и сядь)

proverb: He sits at a table.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. 'to sit at a table' - сидеть за столом; 'to sit on a table' - сидеть на столе

proverb: It's 5 below zero.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'below' is used to indicate that something is at a lower level, but not necessarily under something else. Used in measurements of temperature, height, rankings and in other cases where we think of vertical scale.

proverb: She's below average intelligence.

proverb: The Dead Sea lies below sea level.

It also demonstrates that we need to use the definite article with the names of the follwoing bodies of water: rivers, seas, oceans, canals and gulfs, but not with lakes and waterfalls

proverb: The clouds lingered above the city.

proverb: You have to be 18 or over to see this film.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'over' is mostly used when talking about movement, but it is also used: 1. when something covers something else, clothes, 2. with ages (older than), 3. numbers(more than), speeds, weight

proverb: Over one hundred people came to the party.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'over' is mostly used when talking about movement (as a prepositional adverb), but it is also used: 1. when one thing covers the other, clothes, 2. with ages (older than), 3. numbers(more than), speeds, weight

proverb: I get scared when I drive over 100 kilometers an hour.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'over' is mostly used when talking about movement, but it is also used: 1. when one thing covers the other, clothes, 2. with ages (older than), 3. numbers(more than), speeds, weight

proverb: Put a hand over your mouth when you cough.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'over' is mostly used when talking about movement, but it is also used as a preposition of place: 1. when one thing covers the other, clothes, 2. with ages (older than), 3. numbers(more than), speeds, weight

proverb: Standing between the two adults was a small child.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди)

proverb: On the train I was sitting between two very large men.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). It also demonstrates when to use the preposition 'on' when talking about transport

proverb: There are many differences between English and Arabic.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди)

proverb: There is a trade agreement between Mexico, Canada and the US. Trade agreements exist among countries.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). The first sentence also demonstrates when to use the definite article with country names

proverb: Among the books I saw an old photo. I walked among the trees. There is a traitor among us.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между).

proverb: The donations were distributed among the charities.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между).

proverb: If you walk between those two trees at exactly midnight, a secret gate to another world will open. When you walk among the trees at night, the moonlight looks lovely in your hair.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place and time. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at noon, at midnight, at dinner, etc). 'at night' is an exception that needs to be memorized.

proverb:
- May I be excused?
- No, you may not.
description: This sentence demonstrates when and how to use the modal verb 'may'. In this example it is used to ask for permission and to grant permission. (we can also use 'can' and 'could' to ask for permission, but 'may' is the most polite modal verb to use with permissions). A request is something you ask other people to do, a permission is something you ask to do yourself

proverb: We drove to the airport. We arrived at the airport.
description: These sentences demonstrate the difference between 'to' and 'at'. The preposition 'to' suggests movement, it is a preposition of movement or direction, 'at' suggests a location in place or time. We always say 'arrive at/arrive in' because this verb indicates location, not movement

proverb: The boy on the left is the shortest. The beers to the right of the door, soft drinks to the left.
description: These sentences demonstrate the difference between 'on the left' and 'to the left'. 'on the left' means 'слева', it implies location, to be more precise, it implies the left side, that's why it is used with the preposition of place 'on'. We could also say: The boy on the left side is the shortest. 'to the left' means 'налево', it implies direction, that's why it is used with the preposition of movement/direction 'to'

proverb: She smiled at me. They waved at us as we drove by. She aimed at the target. Don't yell at me!
description: In these sentences 'at' is used as a preposition of direction. The preposition 'at' is usually used as a preposition of location in space or time. But certain verbs are used in combination with this preposition to show direction.

proverb: She threw a stone to me. She threw a stone at me.
description: In these two sentences the prepositions 'to' and 'at' mean the same - direction. But the first sentence means 'бросила камень мне', while the second sentence means 'бросила камень в меня'

proverb: It took us three days to drive across the desert. David walked slowly through the woods.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between two prepositions of movement: across and through. 'across' expresses movement from one side to the other side of something with clear limits such as a city, road or river. The movement is on the surface of something. It is also used as a preposition of place when something touches or stretches from one side to another. 'through' expresses movement into one side and out of the other side of something. The movement is inside something, we are surrounded by it. Notice that these two prepositions are also adverbs, they are sometimes called prepositional adverbs: drive across, walk through.

proverb: The dog ran across the road and nearly got hit by a car. The train goes through a tunnel under the hill.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between two prepositions of movement: across and through. 'across' expresses movement from one side to the other side of something with clear limits such as a city, road or river. The movement is on the surface of something. It is also used as a preposition of place when something touches or stretches from one side to another. 'through' expresses movement into one side and out of the other side of something. The movement is inside something, we are surrounded by it. Notice that these two prepositions are also adverbs, they are sometimes called prepositional adverbs: run across, go through.

proverb: We took a boat across the river. He escaped through a door in the back of the building.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between two prepositions of movement: across and through. 'across' expresses movement from one side to the other side of something with clear limits such as a city, road or river. The movement is on the surface of something. It is also used as a preposition of place when something touches or stretches from one side to another. 'through' expresses movement into one side and out of the other side of something. The movement is inside something, we are surrounded by it. Notice that these two prepositions can also act as adverbs, they are sometimes called prepositional adverbs.

proverb: There are many villages across the border. He looked through the window.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between two prepositions: across and through. 'across' expresses movement from one side to the other side of something with clear limits such as a city, road or river. The movement is on the surface of something (prep of movement). It is also used as a preposition of place when something touches or stretches from one side to the other, or when something is located on the opposite side of something else. 'through' expresses movement into one side and out of the other side of something. The movement is inside something, we are surrounded by it. Notice that these two prepositions can also act as adverbs, they are sometimes called prepositional adverbs.

proverb: The boys swam across the lake. The arrow went through the air.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between two prepositions of movement: across and through. 'across' expresses movement from one side to the other side of something with clear limits such as a city, road or river. The movement is on the surface of something. It is also used as a preposition of place when something touches or stretches from one side to another. 'through' expresses movement into one side and out of the other side of something. The movement is inside something, we are surrounded by it. Notice that these two prepositions are also adverbs, they are sometimes called prepositional adverbs: swim across, go through.

proverb: We went for a walk along the beach at twilight.
description: 'along' is a preposition used to show movement of something in a line that follows the direction of something long. It also demonstrates when to use the preposition of time 'at'

proverb: They rode along narrow country lanes.
description: 'along' is a preposition used to show movement of something in a line that follows the direction of something long.

proverb: They ran down the hill to the stream below.
description: We use 'down' mostly as a preposition or adverb and it indicates a lower position or movement to a lower position. In this particular example 'down' acts as an adverb

proverb: He climbed down the ladder to the bottom of the well.
description: We use 'down' mostly as a preposition or adverb and it indicates a lower position or movement to a lower position. In this particular example 'down' acts as an adverb

proverb: That's five miles down the river.
description: We use 'down' mostly as a preposition or adverb and it indicates a lower position or movement to a lower position. In this particular example 'down' acts as a preposition

proverb: Please, take your papers off my desk. The wine glass fell off the table and shattered on the floor. He jumped off the platform.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition/adverb 'off' indicates movement away from the surface of (and often down) something. Actually this adverb/preposition has many uses and forms a lot of phrasal verbs: take off, turn off, doze off, get off, pay off, finish off, keep off, etc

proverb: I've never been to the sea.
description: We use the Present Perfect Tense to talk about experiences in our life. Here we are not talking about a particular sea, we are talking about sea in general. Similar examples: I've never been to the mountains, I've never been to the country (countryside)

proverb: They went up on to the stage. Move the kettle onto the counter. I slipped as I stepped onto the platform.
description: These sentences demonstrates how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition 'onto/on to' is used to show movement to the top surface of something

proverb: Take your hands out of your pockets and help me! He went out of the room to smoke a cigarette. Get out of the car!
description: These sentences demonstrates how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition 'out of' is used to indicate the enclosed space where a movement begins

proverb: We are flying over the mountains. The cat jumped over the wall.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition 'over' indicates movement above and across the top or top surface of something. Notice that 'over' also acts as an adverb here, such adverbs are sometimes called prepositional adverbs. 'over' can also be a preposition of place

proverb: A beautiful white bird flew over the lake. He threw the ball over the fence and it landed on the roof of a car.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition 'over' indicates movement above and across the top or top surface of something. Notice that 'over' also acts as an adverb here, such adverbs are sometimes called prepositional adverbs. 'over' can also be a preposition of place

proverb: There's a gas station about a mile up the road.
description: 'Up' can be an adverb, a preposition or an adjective. We use 'up' as a preposition to talk about a higher position or movement to a higher position

proverb: Jack and Jill ran up the hill. The boat takes two hours going up the river and one hour coming down. We light the fire every night and that heats the room up.
description: 'Up' can be an adverb, a preposition or an adjective. We use 'up' as an adverb to talk about movement towards a higher position, value, number or level

proverb: The price of fuel is up again. It was cold yesterday but the temperature is up today.
description: 'Up' can be an adverb, a preposition or an adjective. We use 'up' as an adjective usually to talk about increases in prices, levels or amounts

proverb: The mouse ran under the chair. Submarines can travel under water.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition 'under' indicates movement or position directly below something. Actually, in these particular examples 'under' is an adverb, it's a prepositional adverb

proverb: We could see children in the playground as we drove past the school.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this sentence 'past' acts as an adverb and describes movement along something from one side to the other side of it (проезжали мимо)

proverb: We gave the marathoners water as they ran past us.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective, and has many uses. In this sentence 'past' acts as an adverb and describes movement along something from one side to the other side of it (пробегали мимо)

proverb: The office is two blocks past the intersection.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this sentence 'past' acts as a preposition and indicates a location at the farther side of something, beyond a particular place

proverb: Turn left just past the stairs.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this sentence 'past' acts as a preposition and indicates a location at the farther side of something, beyond a particular place (за): Поверните налево сразу за ступеньками

proverb: I'll meet you at half past five. It's exactly ten past three.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In these sentences 'past' is a preposition and is used for saying what time it is when it is not more than thirty minutes after one, two etc o'clock

proverb: Currently the leader of Germany is a woman. Past leaders have all been men.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this example 'past' acts as an adjective and basically means 'прошлый/прошлые'

proverb: It was past midnight by the time we arrived.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this sentence 'past' acts as a preposition and means later than a particular time (за полночь)

proverb: I passed my test by studying past tests.
description: This sentence demonstrates the difference between two homonyms: 'passed' which is a verb (прошел, сдал), and 'past' which is an adjective in this case (прошлые). 'past' has many uses and it can act as a noun, an adjective, an adverb or a preposition

proverb: What would you have done?
description: This is an example of third conditonal sentence. We use third conditional to talk about hypothetical or unreal situations in the past, to imagine a different past. The rule is similar to forming the past perfect tense: when two related events happended in the past. But here the occurrence of one past event depends on the occurrence of another past event

proverb: What would you have done if you had been in my place?
description: This is an example of third conditonal sentence. We use third conditional to talk about hypothetical or unreal situations in the past, to imagine a different past. The rule is similar to forming the past perfect tense: when two related events happended in the past. But here the occurrence of one past event depends on the occurrence of another past event

proverb: I love chocolate. I hate spinach, but I like most other vegetables. I dislike paperwork. What do you want to eat? I want some chocolate.
description: love/hate/like/dislike/want are stative verbs. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: She has always wanted to become a writer.
description: 'want' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: Do you need some help? I need an umbrella. I need a ride.
description: 'need' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'Are you needing some help?', or 'I am needing something'

proverb: I prefer tea to coffee. I'd prefer not to work but I don't have much choice.
description: 'prefer' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am preferring ...'

proverb: She satisfies all the requirements for the job. His job satisfies him.
description: 'satisfy' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am satisfying ...'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective

proverb: I wish you were here.
description: 'wish' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am wishing ...'. Also notice that the verb 'wish' is often used with the subjunctive mood because the meaning is close to something that is unreal. In these unreal situations, past tense does not indicate past time, it distances the situation not in time but in reality. For a wish about a situation in the present, we use the past simple tense

proverb: I hope they get the punishment they deserve.
description: 'deserve' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I hope they get the punishment they are deserving'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective - достойный, заслуживающий. Notice that 'hope' is not a stative verb, we could say 'I am hoping they get the punishment ...' and it would mean the same

proverb: You can do as you please. It pleases me to know that you liked the gift.
description: 'please' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'You can do as you are pleasing'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective

proverb: It doesn't surprise me that their parents don't want them to get married.
description: 'surprise' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'It is not surprising me'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective

proverb: This doesn't concern us at the moment.
description: 'concern' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'this is not concerning us ...'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective or a preposition

proverb: We appreciate your invitation, and will attend the reception.
description: 'appreciate' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'we are appreciating ...' And don't forget that if it is followed by another verb, it must be a gerund, for example: I don't appreciate being ignored.

proverb: I hear some music playing. Did you hear that?
description: 'hear' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am hearing music playing'. But we can say 'I am hearing voices', here hearing means imagining. 'hear' can also be used with 'ing' form as a gerund: hearing - слух, слушание, разбор

proverb: I see her now, she's just coming along the road. I've been seeing my girlfriend for three years.
description: Some verbs can be both stative and dynamic. 'see' as a stative verb means perception with your eyes (видеть) or understanding (first sentence). 'see' as an action verb means to meet / have a relationship with someone (видеться) (second sentence)

proverb: I see what you mean. I'm seeing someone.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'see' as a stative verb means perception with your eyes or understanding (first sentence). 'see' as an action verb means to meet / have a relationship with someone - встречаться с кем-то (second sentence)

proverb: I feel that this is not the best use of our time. I'm feeling sick.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'feel' as a stative verb is used when talking about someone's opinion (first sentence). 'feel' as an action verb is used when experiencing emotions or health issues (second sentence), or touching something - щупать. Actually 'I feel sick' and 'I am feeling sick' mean the same thing and can be used interchangeably. The same is true for 'How do you feel?' and 'How are you feeling?', or 'I feel tired' and 'I am feeling tired'

proverb: I drink because it feels good. I've been feeling unusually tired lately. The doctor is feeling the pulse of a woman.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'feel' as a stative verb is used when talking about someone's opinion (first sentence). 'feel' as an action verb is used when experiencing emotions or health issues (second sentence), or touching something - щупать (third sentence)

proverb: I feel it still needs a lot of work. The vet was feeling the dog's leg to discover if it was broken.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'feel' as a stative verb is used when talking about someone's opinion (first sentence: I think it still needs ...). 'feel' as an action verb is used when experiencing emotions or health issues (I'm not feeling well), or touching something - щупать (second sentence)

proverb: This cheese smells funky. He's smelling the cookies.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'smell' as a stative verb is used to describe the quality of smell possessed by something (пахнуть). 'smell' as an action verb is used when a person uses their nose to test something (нюхать)

proverb: The bar smells of smoke. She is smelling the flower.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'smell' as a stative verb is used to describe the quality of smell possessed by something (пахнуть). 'smell' as an action verb is used when a person uses their nose to test something (нюхать)

proverb: That doesn't sound right. You sound angry.
description: 'sound' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'that is not sounding right' or 'you are sounding angry'

proverb: This soup tastes great. The chef is tasting the soup.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'taste' as a stative verb is used to describe a flavor. 'taste' as a dynamic verb describes an action of tasting something (пробовать на вкус). Very similar to 'smell'

proverb: That cake looks delicious. He's looking at the computer screen.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'look' as a stative verb is used to describe appearance (выглядеть). 'look' as a dynamic verb describes an action of directing your eyes to something (смотреть). Also, as a dynamic verb 'look' forms a lot of phrasal verbs, such as 'look for - искать', 'look after - присматривать', etc

proverb: You look like shit. What are you looking at?
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'look' as a stative verb is used to describe appearance (выглядеть). 'look' as a dynamic verb describes an action of directing your eyes to something (смотреть). Also, as a dynamic verb 'look' forms a lot of phrasal verbs, such as 'look for - искать', 'look after - присматривать', etc

proverb: At what address does he live?
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with specific locations, addresses, public places, shops, hotels, homes etc

proverb: I did not object to the object.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to pronounce 'object' as a noun and as a verb

proverb: Sorry, I don't remember your name. I remember my first day of school like it was yesterday. Do you remember when her birthday is?
description: 'remember' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am remembering my first day ...', or 'Are you remembering when ...?'

proverb: Do you know each other? I don't know the answer. I've known him for years.
description: 'know' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'Are you knowing each other?', or 'I have been knowing him for years'

proverb: He is funny. He is being funny. You are silly. You are being silly.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'be' is usually a stative verb and it is used to show a permanent quality or state of something/someone. But sometimes 'be' can be used as a dynamic verb to show a temporary quality or state, i.e. behaving or acting (only now, not usually). 'He is funny' (it's part of his personality) - он веселый (всегда), 'He is being funny'(he is temporarily behaving this way) - он шутит, он прикалывается (в данный момент), 'You are silly' (it's part of your personality) - ты глуп, 'You are being silly' (you are temporarily behaving this way) - Ты ведешь себя глупо (в данный момент)

proverb: I don't believe you. He believes in God.
description: 'believe' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am not believing you', or 'He is believing in God'

proverb: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
description: 'understand' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am not understanding ...'. By the way, 'mean' is also a stative verb. Understand, know, remember, mean, believe, imagine, suppose, etc describe states of mind.

proverb: I imagine they'll be here quite soon.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'imagine' is mostly used as a stative verb. We can substitute it with 'I think' or 'I am pretty sure'. But sometimes 'imagine' can be used as an action verb, when you are making something up in your head, for example: 'I am imagining things'

proverb: Things are seldom what they seem. It seems to be raining. It seems to me he isn't the right person for the job.
description: 'seem' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: I doubt whether it'll work. No one doubts that the mission will be a success.
description: 'doubt' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: We agree with you. Frank and his wife disagree on this matter. Do you disagree with me?
description: 'agree' and 'disagree' are stative verbs. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: Do you mind if I turn off the light? I don't mind if you don't mind.
description: 'mind (object to)' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: He finally realized the scope of the problem. I realize I was wrong. I realize I should have applied for the visa earlier.
description: 'realize' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: Do you realize the damage you've done?
description: 'realize' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: I suppose you're right. I don't suppose you recognize me.
description: 'suppose' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. By the way, 'recognize' is also a state verb

proverb: I recognized her immediately. We didn't recognize you without your beard.
description: 'recognize' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: She appears to be lost. There appears to be some mistake. Things aren't always what they appear to be.
description: The verb 'appear' has several meanings: to become noticeable/come into sight (появляться), to seem (казаться), to perform publicly (исполнять), to arrive, and others. When it means 'to seem' it is a stative verb.

proverb: I didn't mean to hurt you. What do you mean by that? Material possessions mean nothing to me.
description: 'mean' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: I promise to be back soon. Those gray skies promise rain.
description: 'promise' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective: promising - многообещающий, подающий надежды

proverb: I think you are right. I've been thinking about selling my house.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'think' as a stative verb means to believe, to have an opinion. 'think' as a dynamic verb means to reflect, to ponder - мыслить, размышлять. Notice that when we say 'I've been thinking' it is to indicate a prolonged period of thought, when we've spent quite a bit of time considering a certain matter (Я подумываю продать свой дом)

proverb: I think that's a great idea. I'm thinking about my next holiday.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'think' as a stative verb means to believe, to have an opinion - считать, полагать. 'think' as a dynamic verb means to reflect, to ponder - мыслить, размышлять

proverb: You are stupid. You are being stupid.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'be' is mostly used as a stative verb to show a permanent quality or state of something/someone. But sometimes 'be' can be used as a dynamic verb to show a temporary quality or state (only now, not usually). 'you are stupid' = you are always stupid, it's part of your personality (Ты тупой), 'you are being stupid' = only now, not usually (Ты тупишь)

proverb: It doesn't matter what you think. The only thing that really matters in life are your relationships to other people.
description: 'matter' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: He denies breaking the window. I don't deny that I have made some mistakes. I'm denying myself desserts right now, while I'm on this diet.
description: The verb 'deny' is a stative verb when it means to say that something is not true - отрицать, or to refuse to give something to someone - отказывать (This government denies its citizens basic freedoms). But when it means to deprive oneself (of something) - лишать себя чего-то, it is a dynamic verb and can have both continuous and simple forms. It also demonstrates that if the verb 'deny' is followed by another verb (first sentence), this another verb must be a gerund

proverb: I have a car. I've had this car since 2006. I'm having problems with my car today.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'have' is usully used as a stative verb and means to own, or to do regularly. That's why we use the Present Perfect instead of the Present Perfect Continuous in the second sentence, we can't say: I've been having this car since 2006. But sometimes 'have' can be used as an action verb when taking or experiencing something: I'm having breakfast, I'm having fun, I'm having difficulty, I'm having an affair etc

proverb: I have a headache. I am having a heart attack.
description: The verb 'have' can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation, and it is a little bit tricky with illnesses and conditions. If it is a long-term disease or illness that defines a person's long-term health or a single unchanging short-term condition (cold, fever, headache, toothache, etc), we usually say: I have a cold, I have cancer, I have a fever (think of it as a short-term illness). If it is a current health event that's in the process of changing significantly (приступ чего-то - heart attack, stroke, seizure, asthma attack) we say: I'm having a stroke, I'm having a seizure, etc. Most long term chronic diseases are not countable, but short term diseases and conditions are countable

proverb: I have the flu. She is having a seizure.
description: The verb 'have' can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation, and it is a little bit tricky with illnesses and conditions. If it is a long-term disease or illness that defines a person's long-term health or a single unchanging short-term condition (cold, fever, headache, toothache, etc), we usually say: I have a cold, I have cancer, I have a fever (think of it as a short-term illness). If it is a current health event that's in the process of changing significantly (приступ чего-то - heart attack, stroke, seizure, asthma attack) we say: I'm having a stroke, I'm having a seizure, etc. Most long term chronic diseases are not countable, but short term diseases and conditions are countable

proverb: She has a bath every evening. She is having a bath right now.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'have' is mostly used as a stative verb and means to own, or to do regularly. But sometimes 'have' can be used as an action verb when taking or experiencing something: I'm having breakfast, I'm having fun, I'm having trouble logging into my gmail account, I'm having an affair, I am having a heart attack, etc

proverb: She is having a baby.
description: The verb 'have' can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation, and it is a little bit tricky in this context. 'She is having a baby' is really a short form of 'She is going to have (give birth to) a baby (in the future)', or 'she is pregnant'. It's a set phrase and you need to memorize it. Or it might mean she's having it right now, = giving birth ... depends on the context!

proverb: We're having roast chicken for dinner. I'm having beans for supper.
description: When we are talking about what we are going to eat during a meal we use 'have' as an action verb. 'have' is mostly used as a stative verb and means to own, or to do regularly. But sometimes 'have' can be used as an action verb when taking or experiencing something

proverb: He owns several large companies.
description: 'own' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: This book belongs to the teacher. You don't belong to this world.
description: 'belong' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. But it can be used with 'ing' form as a plural noun: belongings - вещи, пожитки.

proverb: You owe me an apology. I owe the bank a lot of money. How much do I owe you for this?
description: 'owe' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: These trousers fit very well. The dress fits like a glove. My car's too big to fit in this space.
description: 'fit' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. But it can be used with 'ing' form as a noun or adjective.

proverb: Milk contains natural sugar. How much liquid do you think this bottle contains? The letter contains a number of typing errors.
description: 'contain' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: The surfboard measures 2 meters by 55 centimeters. The architects were measuring the distance between the pillars.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'measure' as a stative verb means to be a particular size, when talking about the size of something - иметь размеры. 'measure' as a dynamic verb means to discover the exact size or amount of something - мерить, измерять

proverb: The main bedroom measures 24 ft by 18 ft. The tailor was measuring the gentleman for his new suit.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'measure' as a stative verb means to be a particular size, when talking about the size of something - иметь размеры. 'measure' as a dynamic verb means to discover the exact size or amount of something - мерить, измерять

proverb: The accident involved two cars and a truck. The operation involves inserting a small tube into the heart. It doesn't involve you.
description: 'involve' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. The second sentence also shows that the verb 'involve' is always followed by a gerund (in case it is followed by another verb).

proverb: And I'd just like to say that if it hadn't been for you, Harry and Ron and Hermione, of course... I would still be you know where... so I'd just like to say thanks.
description: This is an example of a mixed conditional. We use a mixed conditional 'If + past perfect, would + infinitive' if the result of an action is in the present.

proverb: This piece of meat weighs two pounds. The butcher is weighing the meat on the scale.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'weigh' as a stative verb is used when talking about the quality possessed by something(have weight - весить). 'weigh' as a dynamic verb is used when someone performs the action of weighing something - взвешивать

proverb: This diet consists of mainly fruit and vegetables. Happiness consists in being satisfied with what you have. Coal consists mostly of carbon.
description: 'consist' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: Success depends on how much effort you make. That depends on the weather. We are depending on you to get this done in time.
