description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. In most cases 'depend' is used as a stative verb and means to be influenced or determined by something else. But we often find it being used in the continuous form, especially when its subject is a person, when one person/people is/are relying on another person right now in a specific situation (полагаться на кого-то).

proverb: The hotel room charge includes breakfast. The report includes detailed financial information for the past five years.
description: 'include' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. But it can be used with 'ing' form as a preposition - включая, в том числе.

proverb: However, for those select few who possess the predisposition, I can teach you how to bewitch the mind and ensnare the senses.
description: 'possess' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: I don't think ghosts exist. Racism still exists in our society. Does life exist on Mars?
description: 'exist' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective - существующий, имеющийся (existing problems - существующие проблемы, under the existing conditions - в нынешних условиях).

proverb: I don't care what she says. He cares deeply about religion.
description: 'care' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective - заботливый, заботящийся, and as a gerund - забота.

proverb: I fear that we are already too late. Police fear the couple may have drowned. What do you fear most?
description: 'fear' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. The last sentence also demonstrates that when we talk about preference we use 'most' without 'the' (больше всего, в большей степени): I like this one most. What matters most to you? What do you fear most? Notice that in these sentences 'most' is an adverb (like most, matters most, fear most), so the rule about needing 'the' with superlative adjectives does not apply here

proverb: How much does it cost? Drinking and driving costs lives.
description: 'cost' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: You resemble your mother very closely. If you surround yourself with clowns, don't be surprised when your life resembles a circus.
description: 'resemble' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: I miss my dad. This table is missing one leg.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'I miss …' relates to a longing for someone or something that has been known or experienced in the past but cannot be found now. 'I am missing …', on the other hand, relates to something that one has lost or misplaced and is searching for, or when something is not there where it should be

proverb: I am on a healthy diet, but I miss chocolate. My sweater is missing a button.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'I miss …' relates to a longing for someone or something that has been known or experienced in the past but cannot be found now. 'I am missing …', on the other hand, relates to something that one has lost or misplaced and is searching for, or when something is not there where it should be

proverb: She is having a baby. She is carrying a baby. She is with child.
description: All three of these phrases mean the same: she is pregnant. Notice that in the last sentence we didn't use 'a' before 'child'. 'she is with a child' means she is spending time with a child or being accompanied by a child. It doesn't indicate that she is pregnant. 'She is with child' indicates a pregnancy.

proverb: The girl is wearing a black dress. The girl wears a black dress every time she goes to church.
description: 'is wearing' usually means that the person is wearing that thing currently, whereas 'wears' usually refers to a pattern of behavior.

proverb: Julia is wearing jeans. Julia wears jeans.
description: 'is wearing' usually means that the person is wearing that thing currently, whereas 'wears' usually refers to a pattern of behavior. The sentence 'Julia wears jeans' means that wearing jeans is something that Julia does (sometimes, all the time, etc.). That can be made more specific, as in 'Julia wears jeans a lot' meaning that wearing jeans is something that Julia does often.

proverb: Most people abhor cleaning their toilets.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'abhor' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'cleaning' is the object of 'abhor'

proverb: The boy acknowledged having lied.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'acknowledge' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'having' is the object of 'acknowledge'

proverb: She admitted to making a mistake.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). Normally, after the word 'to' we use the base form of the verb, but there are some exceptions. Two such exceptions are the verbs 'confess' and 'admit' to doing something. In this sentence, the word 'making' is a gerund and it acts as the object of 'admitted to'. To better understand: the preposition 'to' is part of 'admit to', it does not belong to 'make'. There are some other verbs that follow this pattern: 'devoted', 'dedicated' and 'committed' to doing something, and also 'opposed' or 'object' to doing something.

proverb: I anticipate visiting New York next month.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'anticipate' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'visiting' is the object of 'anticipate'. This sentence also demonstrates when to use 'next' or 'the next'

proverb: You have performed extraordinary magic with this wand, my Lord, in the last few hours alone.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'last' or 'the last'

proverb: I need to get into Gringotts. Into one of the vaults.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with the names of banks

proverb:
Professor Minerva McGonagall:
- Why is it, whenever something happens, it is always you three?
Ron Weasley:
- Believe me, Professor, I've been asking myself the same question for six years.
description: We use the Present Perfect Continuous for something that started in the past and still continues in the present

proverb:
- I guess I don't remember meeting you!
- Well, it's probably because we've never met.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'remember' can be followed by either a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning: 'remember meeting' and 'remember to meet' have two distinct meanings.

proverb: I don't appreciate being ignored.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'appreciate' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'being' is the object of 'appreciate'. And don't forget that 'appreciate' is also a stative verb.

proverb: She avoids dating men over 30.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'avoid' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'dating' is the object of 'avoid'. Also when we want to say that someone is older or younger than a certain age, we use the prepositions 'over' and 'under'

proverb: I try to avoid arguing.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'avoid' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'arguing' is the object of 'avoid'.

proverb: That rule is worth remembering. That's a friend worth having. This movie is worth seeing again.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The collocation 'be worth - заслуживать, стоить' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb: 'remembering', 'having' and 'seeing' are the objects of 'is worth'

proverb: I will help you bear this burden, Frodo Baggins, as long as it is yours to bear.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'bear' (нести груз, нести тяжесть, нести на себе, вынести, вынашивать, терпеть)

proverb: I should've known that you would be here, Professor McGonagall.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use the modal verb 'should' when expressing hindsight advice or regrets

proverb: And some things that should not have been forgotten were lost.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use the modal verb 'should' when expressing hindsight advice or regrets

proverb: And you're lucky to be here, too. A few more hours and you would have been beyond our aid.
description: This is an example of third conditonal sentence. We use third conditional to talk about hypothetical or unreal situations in the past, to imagine a different past. The rule is similar to forming the past perfect tense: when two related events happended in the past. But here the occurrence of one past event depends on the occurrence of another past event

proverb: I can't help being a perfectionist! I can't help thinking about the future. I can't help smiling when I see her.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The collocation can't help which means 'to not be able to control or stop something' (не могу ничего с этим поделать, не могу удержаться чтобы не ...), is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb.

proverb: We'll celebrate working together for over 50 years. He celebrated getting a job.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'celebrate' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'getting' and 'working' are the objects of 'celebrate': мы будем праздновать годовщину совместной работы, он праздновал получение работы

proverb: We're considering selling the house.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'consider' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'selling' is the object of 'consider'.

proverb: We considered leaving early.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'consider' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'leaving' is the object of 'consider' -  мы посчитали что лучше уйти пораньше (мы рассмотрели уход пораньше)

proverb: The lawyer defended her making such statements.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'defend' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'making' is the object of 'defend'. Another example: 'They defended carrying out their actions'

proverb: They defended carrying out their actions.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'defend' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'carrying' is the object of 'defend'.

proverb: She delayed doing her homework.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'delay' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'doing' is the object of 'delay'

proverb: I detest having to get up when it's still dark outside.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'detest - ненавидеть, питать отвращение' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'having' is the object of 'detest'

proverb: We discussed going out. We discussed taking a bus.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'discuss' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'going' and 'taking' are the objects of 'discuss'

proverb: By drinking his blood you've been turned into a vampire.
description: 'turn into' is a phrasal verb which means to change or develop from one thing to another - превращать, превращаться

proverb: The page you were looking for doesn't exist. You may have mistyped the address, or the page may have moved. If you are the application owner check the logs for more information.
description: We use the modal verb 'may+have+p.p' to make guesses about the past. 'might' and 'could' can also be used to show a possibility in the past: You might/could/may have mistyped the address.

proverb: We make for the Gap of Rohan. We should never have come here.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use the modal verb 'should' when expressing hindsight advice or regrets

proverb: I really dislike being interrupted. She dislikes watching TV.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'dislike' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'being' and 'watching' are the objects of 'dislike'. Notice that the verb 'like' can be followed by either an infinitive or a gerund without any change in meaning

proverb: They dispute stealing the merchandise.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'dispute' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'stealing' is the object of 'dispute' - они оспаривают кражу

proverb: I always dread speaking in front of people. I'm dreading having to meet his parents.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'dread' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'speaking' and 'having' are the objects of 'dread'.

proverb: We endured listening to him for three hours.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'endure' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'listening' is the object of 'endure' - Мы терпели его болтовню три часа (дословно: Мы терпели слушание того что он говорит три часа)

proverb: We enjoy hiking. She really enjoys taking pictures of sunsets.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'enjoy' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'hiking' and 'taking' are the objects of 'enjoy'.

proverb: I barely escaped getting caught this time. He escaped dying a slow and painful death.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'escape' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'getting' and 'dying' are the objects of 'escape': Я едва избежал поимки в этот раз, Он избежал умирания медленной и мучительной смертью

proverb: He'll explain purchasing online next week.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'explain' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. In this example 'purchasing' is the object of 'explain' - он объяснит покупки онлайн (как покупать онлайн) на следующей неделе. It also demonstrates when to use 'next' or 'the next'.

proverb: I fear flying in airplanes. I feared entering the room.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'fear' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'flying' and 'entering' are the objects of 'fear'.

proverb: I feel like traveling. Do you feel like going to the theater?
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The collocation 'feel like - быть склонным к чему-либо, хотеть сделать что-либо' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb.

proverb: She finished writing the letter. We've finished preparing for the meeting.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'finish' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'writing' and 'preparing' are the objects of 'finish'.

proverb: You are getting on my nerves. His singing is getting on my nerves.
description: to get on one's nerves - действовать на нервы. You're beginning to get on my nerves - ты начинаешь действовать мне на нервы. He keeps getting on my nerves - Он продолжает действовать мне на нервы

proverb: I gave up smoking two years ago. I will never give up trying to find him.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going).The phrasal verb 'give up', which means to stop or quit, is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'smoking' and 'trying' are the objects of 'give up'.

proverb: They were forced to give in to the enemy. He has tried to give up smoking twice but hasn't succeeded.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between two phrasal verbs 'give in' - уступать, сдаваться противнику, поддаться на уговоры, and 'give up' - бросать вредную привычку, бросать пытаться чего-либо достичь потому что это сложно, бросать какую-то деятельность если она не приносит желаемый результат, бросать пытаться что-либо угадать, и т.п. Also notice that 'give up' is always followed by a gerund

proverb: Our kids kept begging us to take them to the beach, and finally we gave in. After ten minutes trying to get the answer I gave up.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between two phrasal verbs 'give in' - уступать, сдаваться противнику, поддаться на уговоры, and 'give up' - бросать вредную привычку, бросать пытаться чего-либо достичь потому что это сложно, бросать какую-то деятельность если она не приносит желаемый результат, бросать пытаться что-либо угадать, и т.п. And also don't forget that certain verbs, such as 'keep', are always followed by a gerund. Most prepositions are also followed by a gerund: after, in, before, without, with, for, about, etc

proverb: Forgive me for being late. I can't forgive him for getting killed.
description: The verb 'forgive' is usually followed by an object + the gerund or an object + for + the gerund. It can also be followed by a possessive adjective + the gerund: Forgive my being late. Forgive my saying so, but ... This rule also applies to 'excuse' and 'pardon'. Helps to remember: the preposition 'for' is always followed by a gerund

proverb: I go shopping every evening. I've gone camping five times this summer.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive, bare infinitive or gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'shopping' and 'camping' are the objects of 'go'. 'go something' is often used to describe leisure activities that we do in our free time or do for fun: go running, go swimming, go hiking, go fishing, go kayaking, go berry picking, etc. 'go missing' is also a common expression which means to become lost or disappear

proverb: It's hard for me to imagine having children. Imagine spending all that money on a coat!
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'imagine' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'having' and 'spending' are the objects of 'imagine'.

proverb: The job involves working in teams. Leadership involves setting an example that others want to follow.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'involve' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'working' and 'setting' are the objects of 'involve'.

proverb: I think we might have made a mistake leaving the Shire, Pippin.
description: We use the modal verb 'might+have+p.p' to make guesses about the past. 'may' and 'could' can also be used to show a possibility in the past: We might/could/may have made a mistake... Also, the verb 'think' in this context acts as a stative verb: Я полагаю/считаю что мы возможно сделали ошибку ...

proverb: He keeps complaining about his girlfriend. They kept on trying until they succeeded.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'keep/keep on' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'complaining' and 'trying' are the objects of 'keep'.

proverb: They mentioned buying a new car last week. He mentioned having dogs.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'mention' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'buying' and 'having' are the objects of 'mention'.

proverb: I don't mind smoking. Do you mind moving your car?
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'mind' (object to - возражать) is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'smoking' and 'moving' are the objects of 'mind'. And don't forget that 'mind' is also a stative verb.

proverb: Would you mind helping me? Would you mind speaking up a bit? I wouldn't mind having a drink.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The phrase 'would mind / wouldn't mind' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'helping', 'speaking' and 'having' are the objects of 'would mind'. By the way, the verb 'mind' by itself is also followed by a gerund.

proverb: I miss hanging out with my friends. I miss being single.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'miss' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'hanging' and 'being' are the objects of 'miss'. Notice that here 'miss' is a stative verb. It can also be used as a dynamic verb, for example: 'I am missing a button from my sweater'

proverb: We postponed traveling to Chicago for a week.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'postpone' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'traveling' is the object of 'postpone'.

proverb: I practice playing the piano every day.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'practice' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'playing' is the object of 'practice'.

proverb: His disability prevents him from driving. They tried to prevent me leaving.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'prevent (from)' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'driving' and 'leaving' are the objects of 'prevent'.

proverb: What happened?
description: This is an example of subject questions. Subject questions use different word order compared to more commonly used object questions. The subject in a sentence performs the action, and the object is something (person, thing, notion) that is being acted upon, something that receives the action. In object questions we ask about the object. In subject question we ask about the subject, we're focusing on the subject, the 'doer'. We substitute it with the question word (what, who, etc) and we don't use auxiliary verbs.

proverb: What took you so long?
description: This is an example of subject questions. Subject questions use different word order compared to more commonly used object questions. The subject in a sentence performs the action, and the object is something (person, thing, notion) that is being acted upon, something that receives the action. In object questions we ask about the object. In subject question we ask about the subject, we're focusing on the subject, the 'doer'. We substitute it with the question word (what, who, etc) and we don't use auxiliary verbs.

proverb: Who said that? Who did that? Guess what?
description: These are all examples of subject questions. Subject questions use different word order compared to more commonly used object questions. The subject in a sentence performs the action, and the object is something (person, thing, notion) that is being acted upon, something that receives the action. In object questions we ask about the object. In subject question we ask about the subject, we're focusing on the subject, the 'doer'. We substitute it with the question word (what, who, etc) and we don't use auxiliary verbs.

proverb: I have been on vacation for two days. I was on vacation for two days.
description: The first sentence means that you are still on vacation (Я в отпуске уже два дня). The Present Perfect Continuous can't be used here because 'be' is a stative verb in this context. It can also mean that you have recently returned from your vacation and there is some connection to the present (Я только что вернулся с двухдневнего отпуска). The second sentence has no connection to the present and the vacation took place in the past. Note that 'the past' can be recent, like a few days ago. For example: 'I missed the meeting last week because I was on vacation for two days.'

proverb: Tom recalled using his credit card at the store. He does not recollect seeing her at the party.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verbs 'recall' and 'recollect' are always followed by gerunds. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. These two verbs are very similar to 'remember', but 'remember' can be followed by either a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning.

proverb: The plumber recommended buying a new water heater. I highly recommend taking some precautions.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'recommend' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'buying' and 'taking' are the objects of 'recommend'.

proverb: She resents being told what to do. He resents having to work so hard.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'resent - возмущаться/негодовать' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'being' and 'having' are the objects of 'resent'.

proverb: She couldn't resist laughing at him in those clothes. He couldn't resist eating the cake.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'resist' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'laughing' and 'eating' are the objects of 'resist'.

proverb: We resumed speaking about the problem at the meeting.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'resume - возобновлять, продолжать' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'speaking' is the object of 'resume': мы возобновили разговор о проблеме (говорить о проблеме). Also notice that we use the preposition 'at' with events

proverb: He risked being caught. She risks losing her job.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'risk' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'being' and 'losing' are the objects of 'risk'.

proverb: He suggested staying at the Grand Hotel. I suggest reading more English short stories.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'suggest' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'staying' and 'reading' are the objects of 'suggest'.

proverb: I won't tolerate lying. We can't tolerate being screamed at.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'tolerate' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'lying' and 'being' are the objects of 'tolerate'.

proverb: He couldn't understand her leaving so suddenly. I understand being jealous, but you tried to kill me.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The verb 'understand' is always followed by a gerund. The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb. 'leaving' and 'being' are the objects of 'understand'. And don't forget that 'understand' is also a stative verb.

proverb: How long have you worked here? How long have you been working here?
description: These two senteces mean the same and can be used interchangeably.

proverb: Remember to lock the door! I remember locking the door.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'remember' + an infinitive is used for something that you need or needed to do, that has or had to be done, often used when giving advice or an instruction. When 'remember' is followed by a gerund it means you remember something you have done in the past (you have a memory of the action).

proverb: She remembered to visit her grandmother. She remembered visiting her grandmother.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'remember' + an infinitive is used for something that you need or needed to do, that has or had to be done, often used when giving advice or an instruction. When 'remember' is followed by a gerund it means you remember something you have done in the past (you have a memory of the action). The first sentence means that she didn't forget to visit, the second sentence means she had memories of this time

proverb: I forgot to meet him. I forgot meeting him.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'forget' + to + infinitive is used when you want or need to do something, but you forget to do it. Also used when giving advice or an instruction: 'Don't forget to ...  'forget' + gerund is used when you forget about a memory, something that you've done in the past (did it but forgot about it). Often used when talking about past experiences: 'I'll never forget ...

proverb: He forgot to open the window. He forgot opening the window.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'forget' + to + infinitive is used when you want or need to do something, but you forget to do it. Also used when giving advice or an instruction: 'Don't forget to ...  'forget' + gerund is used when you forget about a memory, something that you've done in the past (did it but forgot about it). Often used when talking about past experiences: 'I'll never forget ...

proverb: Don't forget to pick me up from the airport at 4 pm. I'll never forget traveling across Europe.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'forget' + to + infinitive is used when you want or need to do something, but you forget to do it. Also used when giving advice or an instruction: You forgot to pick me up from the airport.  'forget' + gerund is used when you forget about a memory, something that you've done in the past (did it but forgot about it). Often used when talking about past experiences: 'I'll never forget ...

proverb: Don't forget to watch the news tonight! I'll never forget watching my first horror movie!
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'forget' + to + infinitive is used when you want or need to do something, but you forget to do it. Also used when giving advice or an instruction: I forgot to watch the news.  'forget' + gerund is used when you forget about a memory, something that you've done in the past (did it but forgot about it). Often used when talking about past experiences: 'I'll never forget ...

proverb: By the time she finds out, it'll be too late.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition 'by' is used to indicate the end time of an activity, meaning 'no later than'. 'by the time' is a prepositional phrase that can be used for a past, present or a future action and it means 'at some point before - К тому времени как'. 'By the time' is followed by a clause with a relative time that specifies an end or completion time.

proverb: I stopped to smoke. I stopped smoking.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'stop' + to + infinitive is used to indicate that someone stops doing something in order to do something else: 'Я остановился покурить'. 'stop' + gerund is used to indicate that an action or event is no longer continuing: 'Я бросил курить'. Also used when giving advice or an instruction: 'Stop making this noise at once!'

proverb: He decided to stop to drink because he was thirsty. He needs to stop drinking as he is an alcoholic.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'stop' + to + infinitive is used to indicate that someone stops doing something in order to do something else: 'Он решил остановиться чтобы попить воды'. 'stop' + gerund is used to indicate that an action or event is no longer continuing: 'Ему нужно бросить пить'. Also used when giving advice or an instruction: 'Stop making this noise at once!'

proverb: I stopped to talk. I stopped talking.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'stop' + to + infinitive is used to indicate that someone stops doing something in order to do something else: 'Я остановился поговорить.' 'stop' + gerund is used to indicate that an action or event is no longer continuing: 'Я замолчал'. Also used when giving advice or an instruction: 'Stop making this noise at once!'

proverb: I tried to open the window, but it was too heavy. The room was hot and I tried opening the window.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'try + to + infinitive' is used when we attempt to do something that is not easy and usually do not succeed at it: Я попытался открыть окно. 'try + gerund' means to experiment with different options to see if something works, or giving advice: В комнате было жарко и я попробовал открыть окно (как вариант охлаждения комнаты). It's not about whether I can or can't open the window, it's that the room is hot and I need to cool it down somehow

proverb: I'm trying to learn Japanese but it's very difficult. Try studying with someone who speaks the language.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'try + to + infinitive' is used when we attempt to do something that is not easy and usually do not succeed at it: Я пытаюсь выучить Японский. 'try + gerund' means to experiment with different options to see if something works, or giving advice: Попробуй учиться с носителем языка. It also shows the difference between 'learn' and 'study'

proverb: I tried to watch the movie but there was too much noise going on. I couldn't get to sleep so I tried watching the movie.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'try + to + infinitive' is used when we attempt to do something that is not easy and usually do not succeed at it: Я пытался посмотреть фильм, но ... 'try + gerund' means to experiment with different options to see if something works, or giving advice: Я не мог заснуть, поэтому попробовал посмотреть фильм (как альтернативу).

proverb: I regret telling you that I was seeing someone else. I regret to tell you that your grandmother has died.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'regret + gerund' describes a past action which you feel bad about: Сожалею (жалею), что сказал вам, что виделся с кем-то другим. 'regret + to + infinitive' is used in formal expressions, usually in the present tense, to apologize for an unfortunate situation or when announcing bad news: С сожалением сообщаю вам, что ... Also notice that in the first sentence the verb 'see', which is usually a stative verb, is used in the continuous form. 'see' as an action verb means to have a relationship with someone (видеться)

proverb: I regret to inform you that you have failed the exam. I regret not telling you the truth.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. 'regret + to + infinitive' is used in formal expressions, usually in the present tense, to apologize for an unfortunate situation or when announcing bad news: С сожалением сообщаю вам, что ... 'regret + gerund' describes a past action which you feel bad about: Я сожалею (жалею), что не сказал вам правду.

proverb: She quit to work here. She quit working here.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. The first sentence means she left her last job in order to work here. The second sentence means she left her current job, she doesn't work here anymore

proverb: Dave needs to improve his French. My French needs improving.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. The verb 'need' is usually used with an infinitive or an object + an infinitive: Дейву нужно ... When 'need' is used with a gerund, it takes on a passive meaning: Мой французский нуждается... Also notice that 'need' is a stative verb.

proverb: I need to fix my car. My car needs fixing.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. The verb 'need' is usually used with an infinitive or an object + an infinitive: Мне нужно починить... When 'need' is used with a gerund, it takes on a passive meaning: Моя машина нуждается ... We can also say: My car needs to be fixed. Also notice that 'need' is a stative verb.

proverb: I need to clean the window. The window needs cleaning.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. The verb 'need' is usually used with an infinitive or an object + an infinitive: Мне нужно помыть окно. When 'need' is used with a gerund, it takes on a passive meaning: Окно нуждается в мойке (чистке). We can also say: The window needs to be cleaned. Also notice that 'need' is a stative verb.

proverb: He is polite. He is being polite.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'be' is usually a stative verb and it is used to show a permanent quality or state of something/someone. But sometimes 'be' can be used as a dynamic verb to show a temporary quality or state, i.e. behaving or acting (only now, not usually). 'He is polite' means it is in his nature to be polite - он вежлив (всегда), 'He is being polite' means that he is temporarily behaving this way - он пытается быть вежливым (в данный момент)

proverb: After making dinner, I went on to set the table. We can't go on living like this.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. The phrasal verb 'go on + to + infinitive' means to do the next action (change the activity): После того как я приготовил ужин, я начал накрывать на стол. 'go on + gerund' means to continue with the action in the gerund: Мы не можем так дальше жить.

proverb: After introducing her proposal, she went on to speak about the benefits for the company. He went on speaking for two hours.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. The phrasal verb 'go on + to + infinitive' means to do the next action (change the activity): Представив свое предложение, она перешла к обсуждению преимуществ для компании. 'go on + gerund' means to continue with the action in the gerund: Он продолжал говорить (выступать) два часа.

proverb: Go on to read the text. Go on reading the text.
description: Some verbs can be followed either by a gerund or an infinitive with a change in meaning. The phrasal verb 'go on + to + infinitive' means to do the next action (change the activity):  Начни читать текст (Перейди к прочтению текста). 'go on + gerund' means to continue with the action in the gerund: Продолжай читать текст.

proverb: He confessed to stealing the money.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). Normally, after the preposition 'to' we use the base form of the verb, but there are some exceptions. Two such exceptions are the verbs 'confess' and 'admit' to doing something. In this sentence, the word 'stealing' is a gerund and it acts as the object of 'confessed to'. We could also say: 'He confessed to the crime'. We always confess to something. There are some other verbs that follow this pattern: 'devoted', 'dedicated' and 'committed' to doing something, and also 'opposed' or 'object' to doing something.

proverb: She came running across the field. My dog always comes bounding out of the car. All the feelings I once had came rushing back.
description: 'come' can be followed by either an infinitive or a gerund. 'come + gerund' is like other verbs of movement followed by a gerund. It means that the subject is doing something as they move. 'come + infinitive' means that the infinitive verb indicates the purpose of coming, or to have or form an opinion, attitude, etc., after some time: We came to watch a movie. I've come to like her over the months.

proverb: How long have you been awake?
description: We use the present perfect continuous with action verbs (dynamic verbs) to talk about situations that started in the past and have not finished or have just finished. But we can only use the present perfect simple with stative verbs, even though the situation is not finished. Similar examples: How long have you known each other?. How long have you had your car?

proverb: I'm not allowed to bet, but if I could I'd bet on you!
description: This is an example of the second conditional. Second conditional is used in situations/actions in the present or future which are not likely to happen or are imaginary, hypothetical or impossible

proverb: I've been to New York, but I've never seen the Statue of Liberty up close.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of the definite article with famous landmarks and also when to use the present perfect tense

proverb: If God had meant us to fly he'd have given us wings
description: This is an example of third conditonal sentence. We use third conditional to imagine a different past. The rule is similar to forming the past perfect tense: when two related events happended in the past. But here the occurrence of one past event depends on the occurrence of another past event

proverb: It's time you went home. It's time you went to bed.
description: These sentences use the subjunctive mood (сослагательное наклонение). The past subjunctive form is the more commonly used subjunctive form after the phrase 'It's (high) time for something'

proverb: Let me know when you are done being an asshole.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'be' is usually a stative verb and it is used to show a permanent quality or state of something/someone. But sometimes 'be' can be used as a dynamic verb to show a temporary quality or state, i.e. behaving or acting (only now, not usually). 'You are an asshole' (it's part of your personality) - Ты мудак (всегда), 'You are being an asshole'(you are temporarily behaving this way) - ты  ведешь себя как мудак (в данный момент)

proverb: May I bother you for a moment?
description: The modal verb 'may' is used to ask for permission, grant or not grant permission (we can also use 'can' and 'could' to ask for permission, but 'may' is the most polite modal verb to use with permissions)

proverb: You're getting weak. You're getting old. You're getting stronger. You're getting sick. You're getting divorced. It's getting late.
description: You're getting ... - ты становишся ... You're getting weak - ты слабеешь. You're getting old - ты стареешь. You're getting stronger - ты становишся сильнее. You're getting sick - ты заболеваешь. You're getting divorced - ты разводишся. It's getting late - Становится поздно.

proverb: What's on your mind? I have a picture in my mind of a beautiful green valley.
description: 'on my mind' and 'in my mind' have different meanings. 'On my mind' usually refers to something that really bothers you, or something that constantly comes to mind. It isn't necessarily a bad thing, though. On the other hand, 'in my mind' is a much more general and abstract phrase. It means what you think; it means: in your brain, in your head, in your view etc. You're literally picturing something in your mind. It is much more common for people to say 'in my head' rather than 'in my mind'

proverb: I've had a lot of things on my mind these days. I have your phone number in my mind.
description: 'on my mind' and 'in my mind' have different meanings. 'On my mind' usually refers to something that really bothers you, or something that constantly comes to mind. It isn't necessarily a bad thing, though. On the other hand, 'in my mind' is a much more general and abstract phrase. It means what you think; it means: in your brain, in your head, in your view etc. You're literally picturing something in your mind. It is much more common for people to say 'in my head' rather than 'in my mind'

proverb: My stomach hurts. Stop it! You're hurting me!
description: Some verbs have a regular 'active' meaning and a different 'stative' meaning. 'My stomach hurts' means there is a pain in my stomach (У меня болит живот), here 'hurt' is both stative and intransitive and means to feel pain (желудок находится в состоянии боли). You're hurting me! (Ты делаешь мне больно) here 'hurt' is a dynamic transitive verb and means to cause pain to someone

proverb: I laughed. The book fell. She died. He is walking.
description: These sentences demonstrate intransitive verbs. Most sentences in the English language contain a subject and a verb, and many of them contain an object as well: He rode the bike. The verb 'ride' is known as a transitive verb, it has a direct object 'bike'. Intransitive verbs are verbs that do not have an object to receive the action. Some verbs can be both transitive and intransitive: 'The bird sings' and 'The choir sings the national anthem'

proverb: The bird sings. The choir sings the national anthem.
description: Some verbs can be both transitive and intransitive

proverb: I bought some fruit. The fruit was bad.
description: The second time we talk about the same thing in a phrase, we have to use 'the' with it. Also the noun 'fruit' is usually used as an uncountable noun

proverb: Those fish are very colorful. That fish is very colorful.
description: Fish is an irregular unchanging noun. Other examples of irregular unchanging nouns: deer, sheep, moose, aircraft, species (вид/виды), series (серия/серии)

proverb: That sheep is so fat! Those sheep are so fat!
description: Sheep is an irregular unchanging noun. Other examples of irregular unchanging nouns: deer, fish, moose, aircraft, species (вид/виды), series (серия/серии)

proverb: The deer is very beautiful. The deer are very beautiful.
description: Deer is an irregular unchanging noun. Other examples of irregular unchanging nouns: sheep, fish, moose, aircraft, species (вид/виды), series (серия/серии)

proverb: He borrowed a pencil from her. She lent him a pencil.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'borrow' and 'lend'; to borrow - занимать у кого-то, to lend - занимать кому-то; to borrow from / to lend to

proverb: I hold you by your hand. I keep bees.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'hold' and 'keep'; hold - держать что-то в физическом смысле, руками, keep - держать (в смысле содержать), хранить, иметь, продолжать что-то делать, и т.д. 'Keep' is usually permanent. 'Hold' is temporary.

proverb: Can you hold this book for me? Can you keep this book for me?
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'hold' and 'keep'. In the first sentence, you have a book in your hands, and perhaps for some reason you need to use your hands for something else, so you hand over the book to another person. In the second sentence you want the other person to keep possession of the book for a much greater length of time. Maybe you are going out on a trip and you need to leave the book with somebody for safekeeping.

proverb: I used to get up early. I'm used to getting up early. I need to get used to getting up early.
Have you found it? Where did you find it?
description: We use the Present Perfect when we talk about an action in the past that has some bearing on the present, we want to emphasize the importance of an action right now or its result (first question). When we talk about the time of an action or who did it, or where it happened - we use the Past Simple, we don't care about the effect of an action (second question).

proverb: Peter has been a teacher for ten years.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the Present Perfect Tense. We usually use the Present Perfect Continuous for something that started in the past and still continues in the present, but the verb 'be' is a stative verb in this context and can't be used with continuous tenses, that's why the PP is used. But it doesn't mean that Peter is no longer a teacher, he still continues to be a teacher. Similar examples: I've known him for years (and I still know him). Sam has had this car since 2012 (Sam still has his car).

proverb: I've been to the States. I've read many books. Have you ever seen the movie Titanic?
description: One of the main uses of the Present Perfect Tense is to express an experience that happended at some time in one's life. The experience is in the past and finished, but the effects of the action are still felt. When the action happened is not important

proverb: I have bought some food. I have lost my wallet. The taxi hasn't arrived. Have you seen my phone?
description: We use the Present Perfect when we talk about an action in the past that has some bearing on the present, we want to emphasize the importance of the action or the result of it at the present moment. The action is usually in the recent past

proverb: I haven't eaten today, and now I'm hungry! I didn't eat anything for lunch yesterday!
description: We use the PS tense when we are talking about actions which happened in a period of time that has already finished, there is no longer any connection with now. Such sentences usually include special time indicators, for example: yesterday, last week, last month, in 1985, last year. We use the PP tense when we're talking about actions which happened in an unfinished period of time. Such sentences include the following time indicators: today, this morning, this week, this month, this year, ever, never, always.

proverb: I have seen this movie. I saw it at a new cinema theater.
description: We use the Present Perfect to express an experience that happended at some time in one's life, we want to emphasize the fact that we have had such an experience (first sentence). When we talk about the time of an experience or where it happened or how it happened - we use the Past Simple, we don't care about the effect of it (second sentence)

proverb: I've broken my arm. I broke it playing with my cousin.
description: We use the Present Perfect when we talk about an action in the past that has some bearing on the present, we want to emphasize the fact that it happened. The action is usually in the recent past (first sentence). When we talk about the time of an experience or where it happened or how it happened - we use the Past Simple, we don't care about the effect of it (second sentence)

proverb: The message has been sent. The message was sent.
description: The first sentence means that the action happened just now. You would typically see it in your e-mail program just after you send an e-mail. Your program might give you this message to let you know that the message you just sent has indeed been sent. The second refers to something that happened at some time in the past. It could have been an hour ago, a day ago, or even a century ago! But it wasn't just now. The present perfect is called 'present' for a reason. The speaker is talking about the situation now, a situation in which a past event has some bearing on the present. For example: 'The message has been sent' might be followed by a comment such as 'so it's too late to do anything about it now'.

proverb: Last month, I visited my brother three times. This month, I have visited my brother twice.
description: We use the PS tense when we are talking about actions which happened in a period of time that has already finished. Such sentences usually include special time indicators, for example: yesterday, last week, last month, in 1985, last year. We use the PP tense when we're talking about actions which happened in an unfinished period of time. Such sentences include the following time indicators: today, this morning, this week, this month, this year, ever, never, always.

proverb: He borrowed my car yesterday. He has borrowed my car today.
description: We use the PS tense when we are talking about actions which happened in a period of time that has already finished. Such sentences usually include special time indicators, for example: yesterday, last week, last month, in 1985, last year. We use the PP tense when we're talking about actions which happened in an unfinished period of time. Such sentences include the following time indicators: today, this morning, this week, this month, this year, ever, never, always.

proverb: I didn't earn much last year, but I've earned a lot this year.
description: We use the PS tense when we are talking about actions which happened in a period of time that has already finished. Such sentences usually include special time indicators, for example: yesterday, last week, last month, in 1985, last year. We use the PP tense when we're talking about actions which happened in an unfinished period of time. Such sentences include the following time indicators: today, this morning, this week, this month, this year, ever, never, always.

proverb: Julie has never been so quiet. Sandra has worked late since Monday. David has lost a lot of weight since last month.
description: We use the PP tense when we're talking about actions which happened in an unfinished period of time. Such sentences include the following time indicators: today, this morning, this week, this month, this year, ever, never, always. 'since' can also be used to indicate an unfinished period of time, even though it is mostly used with the PPC to indicate a specific time the action started and still continues. But here we are not talking about the duration of an action. For example we could say: 'David has been losing weight since last month'. But now it has a completely different meaning. The PPC indicates that he is still losing weight, the PP indicates his overall change in weight since last month

proverb: Have you thought about looking for a new job? Have you considered telling the truth?
description: We can use the PP tense to make recommendations and give advice. Notice that in the first question we use the -ing form of the verb 'look' because it follows the preposition 'about'. In English all prepositions must be followed by the gerund. And in the second question, the verb 'consider' is followed by the gerund (considered telling). We always use a gerund after another verb when it acts as the object of this verb

proverb: I have just received a new message. I have just taken a shower.
description: We often use the present perfect with 'just' to talk about actions that have happened very recently (like minutes ago), but they have an effect on the present moment

proverb: It is no use running, the train has just left. They have just got married.
description: We often use the present perfect with 'just' to talk about actions that have happened very recently like minutes ago, or days ago (second sentence), but they have a consequence now

proverb: I'm talking to you. I've been talking to you for 5 minutes. It's raining. It has been raining all morning.
description: When we use the present perfect continuous we focus on the duration of the action. We are talking about a period of time during which an action, or state of being, takes place in the present and still continues to take place. If we do not need to indicate a period of time, then we usually use the present continuous.

proverb: How many books has she written? She must be tired, she has been writing all afternoon.
description: When we use the present perfect, we focus on the completion of the action, and its impact on now. When we use the present perfect continuous we focus on the duration of the action.

proverb: You've been playing tennis since 10 o'clock. How many sets have you played?
description: When we use the present perfect, we focus on the completion of the action, and its impact on now. When we use the present perfect continuous we focus on the duration of the action.

proverb: I'm sorry I'm late, have you been waiting for a long time? I think I've liked chocolate since I was born.
description: We use the present perfect continuous with action verbs (dynamic verbs) to talk about situations that started in the past and have not finished or have just finished. But we can only use the present perfect simple with stative verbs, even though the situation is not finished: I think I've liked chocolate since I was born (I still like it)

proverb: It has been raining all morning. How long have you known Peter?
description: We use the present perfect continuous with action verbs (dynamic verbs) to talk about situations that started in the past and have not finished or have just finished. But we can only use the present perfect simple with stative verbs, even though the situation is not finished: How long have you known Peter? (I still know Peter and will know him in the future)

proverb: We've had this TV for ages, I think it's time to buy a new one. I've been having some trouble with my skin recently.
description: We can use both the present perfect simple and the present perfect continuous with how long, for, since, recently to talk about how long a situation has lasted: situations that started in the past and still continue. But we can only use the present perfect simple with stative verbs, in the first sentence 'have' is a stative verb. But sometimes 'have' can act as an action verb when we're experiencing something: problems, fun, a good time, breakfast; or taking something: a bath, a cup of coffee ,etc (second sentence)

proverb: We've had this TV for ages, I think it's time to buy a new one. I've been having stomach problems for the past few days.
description: We can use both the present perfect simple and the present perfect continuous with how long, for, since, recently to talk about how long a situation has lasted: situations that started in the past and still continue. But we can only use the present perfect simple with stative verbs, in the first sentence 'have' is a stative verb. But sometimes 'have' can act as an action verb when we're experiencing or taking something: problems, fun, a good time, a bath, breakfast, a cup of coffee ,etc (second sentence)

proverb: When we arrived at the airport, the flight had left.
description: We use the Past Perfect tense when we're talking about more than one thing that happened in the past. The Simple Past tense we use to talk about one thing that happened in the past and it's over, or even a few things that happened about at the same time more or less. For example we could say: We arrived at the airport at 6:00. The flight left at 5:00. These are two separate sentences that describe two separate events in the past, we didn't yet make any connection between them. But the Past Perfect tense is used when we're talking about two or more things that happened in the past and we want to show which of them happened first in the past. To connect these two events we say: When we arrived at the airport, the flight had left.

proverb: By the time John received the award, he had already directed several movies.
description: We use the past perfect and past simple together to talk about two events in the past and show which one happened first

proverb: John asked me if I had seen his dog.
description: We use the past perfect and past simple together to talk about two events in the past and show which one happened first. This sentence can also be described as reported speech (John: - Have you seen my dog?)'

proverb: Had you had breakfast before you left the house?
description: We use the past perfect and past simple together to talk about two events in the past and show which one happened first

proverb: After I had had a bath, I watched TV.
description: We use the past perfect and past simple together to talk about two events in the past and show which one happened first

proverb: I enjoyed the movie because I had read the book.
description: We use the past perfect and past simple together to talk about two events in the past and show which one happened first

proverb: I had been to India before 1986.
description: The past perfect simple expresses an action taking place before a certain time in the past

proverb: You said you had been to Turkey 5 times.
description: The Past Perfect tense is often used in reported speech. Reported speech is when we talk about something that someone else has said. The way we do this is we take the original sentence and we usually change it into one tense back. The original sentence is 'I have been to Turkey 5 times'

proverb: When we arrived at the cinema, the film had already started.
description: We use the past perfect and past simple together to talk about two events in the past and show which one happened first

proverb: I have been working here for 20 years. I have worked here for 20 years.
description: The verb 'work' (in the sense of having a job) can be used in the present perfect or the present perfect continuous, with no change in meaning. Both sentences communicate the facts that you started working here twenty years ago, worked here over the course of the past twenty years, and that your status of working here has not changed. The same is true for the verb 'live', for example 'I have lived in London for 5 years' and 'I have been living in London for 5 years' have the same meaning.

proverb: I had been waiting there for more than two hours when she finally arrived.
description: The past perfect continuous is used to show that an action started in the past and continued up to another point in the past

proverb: I had been working there for several years before I quit my job.
description: The past perfect continuous is used to show that an action started in the past and continued up to another point in the past

proverb: I had been working at the company for five years when I got the promotion.
description: The past perfect continuous is used to show that an action started in the past and continued up to another point in the past

proverb: Anna failed the exam because she had been skipping classes.
description: The past perfect continuous is used to show that an action started in the past and continued up to another point in the past

proverb: Had you been waiting long before the taxi arrived?
description: The past perfect continuous is used to show that an action started in the past and continued up to another point in the past

proverb: When you arrive, the bus will have left. By the time you get here, I will have finished watching the movie.
description: The future perfect is a verb tense used for actions that will be completed before some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future or another action in the future. If it is another action in the future, the action is described using the Present Simple tense (when you arrive, when he arives, when I arrive, by the time you get here, by the time he gets here, etc). Notice that the verb 'finish' is always followed by a gerund

proverb: When she wakes up, he will have gone to work. Next week we'll have been together for two years.
description: The future perfect is a verb tense used for actions that will be completed before some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future (second sentence) or another action in the future (first sentence). Notice that if it is another action in the future, the action is described using the Present Simple tense (when she wakes up, when you wake up, when I wake up)

proverb: I won't have finished work by 8 p.m. Will you have eaten when I pick you up?
description: The future perfect is a verb tense used for actions that will be completed before some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future or another action in the future. If it is another action in the future, the action is described using the Present Simple tense (when I pick you up, when he picks you up, etc)

proverb: By the time you read this I will have left. Will you have finished when I get back?
description: The future perfect is a verb tense used for actions that will be completed before some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future or another action in the future. If it is another action in the future, the action is described using the Present Simple tense (when I get back, when he gets back, when you get back, etc)

proverb: In November, I will have been working at my company for three years.
description: Like the future perfect simple, future perfect continuous is used to project ourselves forward in time and to look back. It refers to events or actions that are currently unfinished and will still be in progress at some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future (in November) or another action in the future. It is most often used with a time expression (for three years). Remember that nonaction verbs like to be, to seem, or to know are not suited to the future perfect continuous tense. Instead, these verbs take the future perfect tense, for example: On Thursday, I will have known you for a week.

proverb: I will have been waiting here for three hours by six o'clock.
description: Like the future perfect simple, future perfect continuous is used to project ourselves forward in time and to look back. It refers to events or actions that are currently unfinished and will still be in progress at some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future (by six o'clock) or another action in the future. It is most often used with a time expression (for three hours). Remember that nonaction verbs like to be, to seem, or to know are not suited to the future perfect continuous tense. Instead, these verbs take the future perfect tense, for example: On Thursday, I will have known you for a week.

proverb: You will have been waiting for 2 hours when I arrive.
description: Like the future perfect simple, future perfect continuous is used to project ourselves forward in time and to look back. It refers to events or actions that are currently unfinished and will still be in progress at some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future or another action in the future (when I arrive). If it is another action in the future, the action is described using the Present Simple tense (when I arrive). Remember that nonaction verbs like to be, to seem, or to know are not suited to the future perfect continuous tense. Instead, these verbs take the future perfect tense, for example: On Thursday, I will have known you for a week.

proverb: In ten minutes you will have been driving non-stop for six hours.
description: Like the future perfect simple, future perfect continuous is used to project ourselves forward in time and to look back. It refers to events or actions that are currently unfinished and will still be in progress at some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future (in 10 minutes) or another action in the future. It is most often used with a time expression (for six hours). Remember that nonaction verbs like to be, to seem, or to know are not suited to the future perfect continuous tense. Instead, these verbs take the future perfect tense, for example: On Thursday, I will have known you for a week.

proverb: On Thursday, I will have known you for a week.
description: Like the future perfect simple, future perfect continuous is used to project ourselves forward in time and to look back. It refers to events or actions that are currently unfinished and will still be in progress at some other point in the future, either a specific time in the future (On Thursday) or another action in the future. It is most often used with a time expression (for a week). Remember that nonaction verbs like to be, to seem, or to know are not suited to the future perfect continuous tense. Instead, these verbs take the future perfect tense

proverb: I'm going to eat pizza. I will eat pizza.
description: In English there is no difference in meaning between 'going to' and 'will'. Both can be used interchangeably

proverb: He asked me what I was doing
description: He asked me what I was doing - он спросил меня, что я делаю. (He asked me what I am doing - неправильно). This is an example of reported speech

proverb: He was angry at her for staying out so late. The workers are angry about the new measures.
description: We are 'angry at/with somebody' but 'angry about/over something'

proverb: I was angry with him for forgetting my birthday. She's still angry over the way she's been treated.
description: We are 'angry at/with somebody' but 'angry about/over something'

proverb: What's the weather today? How's the weather today?
description: The first question focuses more on the objective description of the weather (is it sunny, cloudy, windy, rainy, etc.) The second question focuses more on someone's subjective opinion of the weather. The listener can answer this question the same way as 'what is the weather today' by replying that it's sunny, cloudy, etc., but using 'how' instead of 'what' also gives the listener the freedom to answer with 'it is wonderful' or 'it is terrible' without mentioning the actual weather conditions.

proverb: The gentleman whose cell phone was stolen was very upset. The car whose left door is scratched is going to be repaired next week.
description: 'whose' is a possessive determiner or pronoun (mine, ours, yours, his, hers, its, etc), it means possession and is used for adding information about a person or thing. Also notice that in both sentences 'whose' is part of an identifying relative clause

proverb: Do you know whose car that is? The company, whose workers are now being forced to stay home, will probably go bankrupt.
description: 'whose' is a possessive determiner or pronoun, it means possession and is used for adding information about a person or thing.

proverb: A computer can be compared to a filing cabinet. London is a boring city compared with Paris.
description: The difference between 'compared to' and 'compared with'. When comparing things that are different in nature, use TO (first sentence). When comparing things that are similar in nature, use WITH (second sentence)

proverb: The way he delivered his speech could be compared to a waterfall hitting the rocks with great force. My parents are quite strict, but they're not so bad compared with yours.
description: The difference between 'compared to' and 'compared with'. When comparing things that are different in nature, use TO (first sentence). When comparing things that are similar in nature, use WITH (second sentence)

proverb: The children are in bed. We didn't get out of bed until after one o'clock. She sat on the bed in my room.
description: Bed is a strange word. If we don't use an article, it means a place where we sleep (uncount noun), not a particular object (first two sentences). Fixed expressions: (go) to bed, (be) in bed, make the bed (застилать кровать). But when we are thinking about a bed as an object (count noun), we use articles in the normal way (third sentence)

proverb: She got home and went straight to bed. I need to buy a new bed.
description: Bed is a strange word, similar to home and work. If we don't use an article, it means a place where we sleep (uncount noun), not a particular object (first sentence).
