Fixed expressions: (go) to bed, (be) in bed, make the bed (застилать кровать). But when we are thinking about a bed as an object (count noun), we use articles in the normal way (second sentence)

proverb: They went home. I stayed at home. Julie works from home. It's time to go home. We arrived home yesterday. We visited the home of Jackie Kennedy.
description: The word home is a bit strange. If we don't use an article, it means a place where we live (uncount noun), or it can also be an adverb like in: go home, arrive home, stay home, etc.. Fixed expressions: (go) home, be (at) home, arrive home. Notice we don't need 'to' with 'go home' (not 'go to home'). But we can use an article with home when it means 'the building that somebody lives in'. In this case we use articles in the normal way (the last sentence)

proverb: They went home. I stayed at home. Julie works from home. It's time to go home. We arrived home yesterday. My sister has made her flat into a beautiful home.
description: The word home is a bit strange. If we don't use an article, it means a place where we live (uncount noun), or it can also be an adverb like in: go home, arrive home, stay home, etc. Fixed expressions: (go) home, be (at) home, arrive home. Notice we don't need 'to' with 'go home' (not 'go to home'). But we can use an article with home when it means 'the building that somebody lives in'. In this case we use articles in the normal way (the last sentence)

proverb: I'm home! I'm at home!
description: Both these expressions are correct, but they are used in different contexts. 'I am home!' is a very popular expression which means 'I am back!' It is what you say when you walk in through the door to tell people there that you've arrived: Honey, I'm home! On the other hand 'I am at home' is used to describe where you are currently located: -Where are you right now? -I'm at home, what about you?

proverb: I always arrive at work on time. The work I'm doing at the moment is very interesting. The thieves stole several valuable works of art.
description: The noun 'work' is similar to 'home' and 'bed'. When we use 'work' to mean a place where we work, then we don't need to use an article (first sentence). Fixed expressions: (go) to work, (be) at work, start work, finish work, leave for work. When we use 'work' to mean a project that we are working on now, 'work' is a normal uncountable noun. So, we can use 'the' if we are talking about some specific work that the listener knows about (second sentence). An exception is when work means a piece of art/literature/music (произведение искусства, шедевр, творение). In this case work is a normal countable noun (third sentence)

proverb: The twins enjoy school. Bob and Kevin go to the same school. When I was in high school, everyone had to study French. Don't be late for school! They built a new school not far from my house.
description: School is a strange word! When we are talking about school in the general sense of education, we do not use articles with it (abstract uncountable noun similar to home or work). Fixed expressions: (go) to school, (be) at/in school, start school, finish school. It can also mean a building where children/adults receive education, then we can say 'a school' or 'the school' (the last sentence).

proverb: He is still in school. He is still at school.
description: These two expressions have different meanings. The first expression means that he is still a student (он все еще школьник/студент). The second expression means that he still hasn't come back from school today, just like we would say that we are 'still at work'

proverb: I was told off for talking in class. Okay, class, settle down and open your books.
description: The noun 'class' has two meanings: a period of time in which students are taught something (можно перевести как урок) (first sentence), or a group of students who are taught together (second sentence). Fixed expressions: be in class, take/have a class, give/hold/teach a class. A teacher gives/holds/teaches a class. Students take or have classes.

proverb: I met Charles while I was in town. He left town after he argued with his wife. Sitka is a lively and charming small town with restaurants, shops, and even art galleries.
description: When we are talking about the place where we live or work, or about the town center near to us, 'town' is an uncountable noun (just like downtown) and we often use no article with it in certain expressions: in town, go into town, out of town, leave town. Town can also be a normal countable noun (last sentence)

proverb: I was at church. I was in the church.
description: 'I was at church' implies that you were attending a service(богослужение): praying, listening to a sermon, etc. 'I was in the church' implies that you just happened to be physically in the building but not necessarily attending a service. It's very similar to how 'school' is used. Fixed expressions when talking about church as a religious service: (go) to church, (be) at church. Fixed expressions when talking about a building or a religious organization: (go) to a/the church, (be) in a/the church

proverb: I met her at church. I met her at the church. I met her in the church.
description: 'I met her at church' implies that you met her while attending a service(богослужение), just as we can say 'I met her at school'. 'I met her at the church' implies that you met her at the location which is the church (inside or outside). Here the church means the building or the physical location. 'I met her in the church' literally means you met her inside the building.

proverb: Charles hasn't gone to church in ages. The workmen went to the church to repair the roof.
description: When we are talking about attending a service(богослужение): praying, listening to a sermon, etc., then we use 'go to church'. Fixed expressions: (go) to church, (be) at church. We use articles with 'church' when we refer to a building or a religious organization. Fixed expressions: (go) to a/the church, (be) in a/the church

proverb: He is in prison. He is in the prison.
description: The phrase 'He is in prison' means that he is confined in a prison somewhere, it indicates his status as a prisoner. The phrase 'He is in the prison' refers to his physical presence in a specific prison complex, but not necessarily as a convict. He might be visiting or working there as a guard. 'in jail' vs 'in the jail' works in the same manner

proverb: She went to prison. She went to the prison.
description: She went to prison = She is a convict. She went to the prison = She is not a convict, perhaps a visitor. More concrete examples: She went to prison for killing her husband. She went to the prison to visit her husband. 'go to jail' and 'go to the jail' works in the same manner

proverb: She went to prison for killing her husband. She went to the prison to visit her husband.
description: 'She went to prison' implies she was sent there for her crimes. 'She went to the prison' means she were just visiting her jailed husband. 'go to jail' vs 'go to the jail' works in the same manner

proverb: He went to jail for domestic violence. She went to the jail to visit her husband.
description: 'He went to jail' implies he was sent there for his crimes. 'She went to the jail' means she were just visiting her jailed husband. 'go to prison' vs 'go to the prison' works in the same manner

proverb: Gryffindor wins! The Irish national Quidditch team won the 1994 Quidditch World Cup.
description: In the seconds after you win, you can say 'I win!' or 'Somebody wins!' or 'You win!'. Five minutes later/20 years later, you must say 'I won' or 'Somebody won' when referring to the same contest.

proverb: I am in the street. I am at the street. I am on the street.
description:
'I am in the street' usually means you are on the pavement of the street possibly where you can get hit by car, as one would tell children 'Get out of the street!'
'I am at the street' is usually used to say you have arrived at a street e.g. an intersection with another street 'I am at Fifth Avenue and 43rd St'
'I am on the street' is used to say you're somewhere along the street 'He lives on Mitchell Avenue' means he lives somewhere along Mitchell Avenue.

proverb: Maybe it will rain tomorrow. I may be a little late for lunch.
description:
'maybe' as one word is an adverb and means 'possibly'. It often comes in front of a subject and verb: maybe + subject + verb + the rest of the sentence.
'may be' as two words is actually a modal verb 'may' + the main verb 'be'. The sentence structure is: subject + may + be + the rest of the sentence.

proverb: He is so tall. He is such a tall man. They are so friendly. They are such friendly people. He runs so quickly. She speaks so slowly.
description: The word 'so' should be used with an adjective or an adverb. The word 'such' should be used with a noun, it could be a singular noun or a plural noun. There are also a couple of other expressions which you should be familiar with: so long, so much, so many, such a long time, such a lot of time. For example: It's been so long since I saw you. It's been such a long time since we last met. We have so much time before our flight. We have such a lot of time before our flight

proverb: Can you please do the dishes? I did the laundry last night. Don't forget to make the bed. My husband dresses the children while I make breakfast.
description: When to use 'do' and when to use 'make' when talking about chores. 'do' is basically a replacement for the word 'wash'. Other examples: do the bathroom (clean the bathroom), do the windows (wash the windows). 'make' basically means 'create'. Other examples: make a cup of coffee, make a mess

proverb: Karen was very tired during the day, because she hadn't slept all night. Rita often listens to music while doing her homework.
description: 'during' is always followed by a noun, 'while' is always followed by a verb, usually in continuous form

proverb: During the flight I slept a lot. While I was flying I slept a lot.
description: 'during' is always followed by a noun, 'while' is always followed by a verb, usually in continuous form

proverb: I got a beer. I took a beer.
description: We usually use 'get' or 'got' when we passively obtain or receive something (получать), when someone gives something to us. Usually there are two people involved (you and the person who gives you something). The first sentence means someone gave you the beer, a bartender for example. With 'take' there is only one person (you) who actively performs the action (брать). 'I took a beer' could mean you personally went to the fridge opened it and took the beer. 'take' can also mean to steal something. Other examples: take a dump (no one there, only you), take a piss, take a flight, take a shower, get sick (passively obtain a sickness), get a raise (the boss gave you a raise), get a cold (someone infected you), get fired (someone fired you, you can't fire yourself)

proverb: For his birthday, Mike got a brand new drill set. Helen has high blood pressure, so she takes pills every day.
description: We usually use 'get' or 'got' when we passively obtain or receive something (получать), when someone gives something to us. Usually there are two people involved (you and the person who gives you something). With 'take' there is only one person (you) who actively performs the action (брать, принимать). 'take' can also mean to steal something. Other examples: take a dump (no one there, only you), take a piss, take a flight, take a shower, get sick (passively obtain a sickness), get a raise (the boss gave you a raise), get a cold (someone infected you), get fired (you can't fire yourself)

proverb: Last winter, Christine didn't get sick even once. I asked my dad to lend me his car. He said no, but I took it anyway.
description: We usually use 'get' or 'got' when we passively obtain or receive something (получать), when someone gives something to us. Usually there are two people involved (you and the person who gives you something). With 'take' there is only one person (you) who actively performs the action (брать, принимать). 'take' can also mean to steal something. Other examples: take a dump (no one there, only you), take a piss, take a flight, take a shower, take pills, get a coffee (at a coffee shop), get a raise (the boss gave you a raise), get a cold (someone infected you), get fired (you can't fire yourself)

proverb: I'm listening to the radio. I hear some music playing.
description: 'listen - слушать' is active, you are paying attention and concentrating when you're listening to something. 'hear - слышать' on the other hand is a little bit more passive, you're just receiving sound whether you want it or not without paying attention. 'hear' is a stative verb, 'listen' is dynamic. 'look' and 'see' work in the same manner. 'Hearing' and 'seeing' are abilities that people have, they are automatic, we don't have to make an effort to do them. 'Listening' and 'looking' require effort

proverb: Did you hear what I just said? No, sorry, I wasn't listening.
description: 'listen - слушать' is active, you are paying attention and concentrating when you're listening to something. 'hear - слышать' on the other hand is a little bit more passive, you're just receiving sound whether you want it or not without paying attention. 'hear' is a stative verb, 'listen' is dynamic. 'look' and 'see' work in the same manner. 'Hearing' and 'seeing' are abilities that people have, they are automatic, we don't have to make an effort to do them. 'Listening' and 'looking' require effort

proverb: Look over there! What can you see?
description: 'look/look at - посмотреть' means to purposefully direct your eyes in a particular direction to see something, it's active, it requires effort. 'see - видеть, увидеть' is passive, you are receiving the image thru your eyes but you are not necessarily focusing on it. Both 'look' and 'see' can act as stative and dynamic verbs. 'watch - смотреть, наблюдать, следить (длительный процесс)' is also active, you are deliberately focusing your eyes on something or someone for an amount of time and pay attention to what is happening. 'listen' and 'hear' work in the same manner. 'Hearing' and 'seeing' are abilities that people have, they are automatic, we don't have to make an effort to do them. 'Listening', 'looking' and 'watching' require effort

proverb: Did you see that? No, I wasn't looking.
description: 'look/look at - посмотреть' means to purposefully direct your eyes in a particular direction to see something, it's active, it requires effort. 'see - видеть, увидеть' is passive, you are receiving the image thru your eyes but you are not necessarily focusing on it. Both 'look' and 'see' can act as stative and dynamic verbs. Ты видел это? Нет, я не смотрел. 'watch - смотреть, наблюдать, следить (длительный процесс)' is also active, you are deliberately focusing your eyes on something or someone for an amount of time and pay attention to what is happening. 'listen' and 'hear' work in the same manner. Compare: Did you hear that? No, I wasn't listening. 'Hearing' and 'seeing' are abilities that people have, they are automatic, we don't have to make an effort to do them. 'Listening', 'looking' and 'watching' require effort

proverb: I watched a man digging a hole. I saw a man digging a hole.
description: The first expression means that you sat or stood there and observed the whole or a large part of the process. The second expression means that you walked down the street for example and just noticed that there was a man digging a hole without paying much attention

proverb: In order to learn English, I had to study really hard.
description: In English, 'learn' means to gain knowledge or skill (освоить, научиться). 'study' refers to the process of gaining knowledge or skill, especially if you are a student preparing for an exam or test. Studying involves sitting at a table, reading books on a subject, writing notes, etc. However, when we speak about the process of gaining a practical skill that doesn't involve reading or writing, for example riding a bike, speaking in public, playing a musical instrument or playing football, we use learn, not study. For example: I'm learning how to drive, I'm learning to play the piano

proverb: Where did you learn how to bake so well? Did you study baking in school?
description: To study means to read, memorize facts or attend school in order to learn about a subject (изучать, исследовать). To learn means to gain knowledge or skill by studying, practicing, being taught or experiencing something (узнавать, научиться чему-либо). Learning is gaining knowledge by studying, and studying is done to learn things. Here's an expression that helps to better understand the difference: 'I studied but I did not learn anything'

proverb: I hope you learned something from studying today's lesson!
description: In English, 'learn' means to gain knowledge or skill (освоить, научиться). 'study' refers to the process of gaining knowledge or skill, especially if you are a student preparing for an exam or test. For example: I'm learning how to drive, I'm learning to play the piano. You can study how to drive by reading about driving, but when you are in a car and your hands are on the steering wheel you are actually learning how to drive

proverb: I'm studying law at Harvard. I study law at Harvard.
description: These two expressions are both correct and can be used interchangeably. With some verbs, such as study, work, live, the choice of aspect makes little difference. The meanings are similar, however it is preferable to use 'I am studying', to emphasize the fact that it's just temporary - someday you will finish your studies and do something else.

proverb: I am hoping to get a raise soon. I hope to get a raise soon.
description: These two expressions are both correct and can be used interchangeably. 'hope' is not a stative verb. It has a continuous form and a simple form. There is a slight difference in meaning. It is only a rhetorical difference. The 'I am hoping' refers to an emotion that is currently in progress. You are referring to feelings that you are currently directly feeling. On the other hand I hope' is a general statement of fact, it is plainer and less emotive. It would be used for more serious longer-term desires.

proverb: I'm going to the park tomorrow, so I hope it won't rain. I'm going to the park tomorrow, so I'm hoping it won't rain.
description: These two expressions are both correct and can be used interchangeably. 'hope' is not a stative verb. It has a continuous form and a simple form. There is a slight difference in meaning. On the other hand I hope' is a general statement of fact, it is plainer and less emotive. It would be used for more serious longer-term desires.

proverb: Do you have the time? Do you have time?
description: If someone asks you 'Do you have the time?', they basically ask 'What time is it?'. If someone asks you 'Do you have time?', they want to know if you are free to talk to you about something or to help them with something

proverb: I had my car fixed. I had the package delivered. My hair is too long, I should get it cut by a barber. My teeth hurt, I should have them looked at by a dentist.
description: These are all examples of passive causative. Passive causative is when you have something done by someone else. The agent (person or thing that performs the action) is often implicit (first two sentences). It is also often used when giving advice: 'Your hair is too long, you should get it cut by a barber' or just 'You should get it cut!'. The two most common causative verbs are 'get' and 'have'. 'make' and 'let' are also used but very rarely

proverb: I am a teacher. He told me he was a teacher.
description: Reported speech is when we talk about something that someone else has said. The way we do this is we take the original sentence and we usually change it into one tense back. To say 'He told me he is a teacher' is incorrect. Another examples: 'They lived in Russia' becomes 'He told me they had lived in Russia'. We use the Past Perfect here because if we use the Present Perfect it won't be reported speech anymore, because the PP tense is a present tense. In reported speech the Past Simple and the Present Perfect are turned into the Past Perfect tense; 'They will live in Russia' becomes 'He told me they would live in Russia'

proverb: I haven't seen Mike. He said that he hadn't seen Mike.

proverb: I can speak perfect English. She said she could speak perfect English.

proverb: The girl whose purse I found called me to return it.
description: There are two types of relative clauses (придаточных предложений): identifying and non-identifying. An identifying clause identifies the subject of a sentence. It gives more information about it. Without this information the sentence won't be complete and will lose its meaning. We can't just say: 'The girl called me to return it'. Which girl? The subject + the identifying clause together can be viewed as a complete subject. We do not use commas to highlight an identifying clause. Also notice that 'whose', which is a possessive pronoun, can be used for adding information about people or things.

proverb: The movie which I saw last weekend was excellent.
description: There are two types of relative clauses (придаточных предложений): identifying and non-identifying. An identifying clause identifies the subject of a sentence. It gives more information about it. Without this information the sentence won't be complete and will lose its meaning. We can't just say: 'The movie was excellent'. Which movie? The subject + the identifying clause together can be viewed as a complete subject. We do not use commas to highlight an identifying clause. Also remember that we can use 'that' and 'which' with identifying clauses interchangeably (when talking about things). With non-identifying clauses, when talking about things, we can only use 'which', and when talking about people we can only use 'who'

proverb: I saw a car which was white.
description: There are two types of relative clauses (придаточных предложений): identifying and non-identifying. An identifying clause identifies the subject of a sentence. It gives more information about it. Without this information the sentence won't be complete and will lose its meaning. We can't just say: 'I saw a car'. Which car? proverb: That's the street which I grew up on.
description: There are two types of relative clauses (придаточных предложений): identifying and non-identifying. An identifying clause identifies the subject of a sentence. It gives more information about it. Without this information the sentence won't be complete and will lose its meaning. We can't just say: 'That's the street'. Which street? The subject + the identifying clause together can be viewed as a complete subject. We do not use commas to highlight an identifying clause. Also remember that we can use 'that' and 'which' with identifying clauses interchangeably (when talking about things). With non-identifying clauses, when talking about things, we can only use 'which', and when talking about people we can only use 'who'

proverb: Harry Potter, which I finished last week, was an excellent book.
description: There are two types of relative clauses (придаточных предложений): identifying and non-identifying. We use non-identifying clauses to provide additional information about the subject, without which the sentence will still be complete and understood. We can just say: 'Harry Potter was an excellent book' because everybody knows about Harry Potter. We have to use commas to highlight a non-identifying clause. Also remember that with non-identifying clauses (extra information about things or people) we can't use 'that', only 'which' or 'who'.

proverb: Toronto, which is heavily populated, is a multicultural city.
description: There are two types of relative clauses (придаточных предложений): identifying and non-identifying. We use non-identifying clauses to provide additional information about the subject, without which the sentence will still be complete and understood. We can just say: 'Toronto is a multicultural city'. We have to use commas to highlight a non-identifying clause. Also remember that with non-identifying clauses (extra information about things or people) we can't use 'that', only 'which' or 'who'.

proverb: The man who lives next door is a doctor. Dr. Smith, who lives next door, is a retired surgeon.
description:
There are two types of relative clauses (придаточных предложений): identifying and non-identifying. An identifying clause identifies the subject of a sentence. Without it the sentence won't be complete and will lose its meaning. We can't just say: 'The man is a doctor'. What man? We do not use commas to highlight an identifying clause.
A non-identifying clause provides extra information about the subject, without which the sentence will still be complete and understood. We have to use commas to highlight a non-identifying clause. We can just say: 'Dr. Smith is a retired surgeon.' Also remember that with non-identifying clauses (extra information about things or people) we can't use 'that', only 'which' (for things) or 'who' (for people).

proverb: My sister who is from Chicago visited me last weekend. My sister, who is from Chicago, visited me last weekend.
description: The difference between these two sentences is that the first sentence contains an identifying clause and it means that you have many sisters. You need to provide this additional information to identify which sister you are talking about. We do not use commas to highlight an identifying clause. The second sentence contains a non-identifying clause and it means that you have only one sister. So, if you just say 'My sister visited me last weekend', it will be complete and understood by a listener, because you have only one sister and everybody knows that she lives in Chicago, so this information is extra. We have to use commas to highlight a non-identifying clause.

proverb: Which is the farthest planet from the Sun?
description: The adjectives 'good', 'bad', and 'far' are irregular, their superlative forms are the best, the worst and the farthest/furthest

proverb: On average, it rains once a week here. On an average day, I get five phone calls.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between 'on average' and 'on an average'. 'on average' just means 'в среднем', it doesn't require any additional articles. The use of an article (in this case the indefinite article 'an') can only be used if 'average' is followed by a noun: on an average day/week/month, etc. Don't say 'on the average', it is not used in BrE and is very rare in AmE

proverb: I wish I were taller. I wish he were a nicer person. I wish I hadn't eaten so much. I wish the sun would come out.
description: 'wish' is a unique verb in English. It is often used with the subjunctive mood because the meanings are imaginary. In these unreal situations, past tense does not indicate past time, it distances the situation not in time but in reality. It is very close to the second conditional in meaning: If I were taller, I would play basketball. For a wish about a situation in the present (first two sentences), we use the past simple tense: 'I am not tall' becomes 'I wish I were taller'. Notice that 'were' is used for all pronouns. For past wishes (regrets), we go back in the past one tense further: 'I ate too much' becomes 'I wish I hadn't eaten so much'. Use 'would' for wishes in the future or to complain about the present situation and describe a future remedy (last sentence): 'It is cloudy today. I wish the sun would come out.'

proverb: I wish I were rich. He wishes he were taller. I wish I had studied harder in high school. I wish it would rain.
description: 'wish' is a unique verb in English. It is often used with the subjunctive mood because the meanings are imaginary. In these unreal situations, past tense does not indicate past time, it distances the situation not in time but in reality. It is very close to the second conditional in meaning: If I were rich, I would buy ... For a wish about a situation in the present (first two sentences), we use the past simple tense:'I am poor' becomes 'I wish I were rich'. Notice that 'were' is used for all pronouns. For past wishes (regrets), we go back in the past one tense further, i.e use the past perfect tense: 'I didn't study hard in high school' becomes 'I wish I had studied harder in high school'. Use 'would' for wishes in the future or to complain about the present situation and describe a future remedy (last sentence): 'It hasn't rained for two weeks. I wish ...'

proverb: He is in a meeting. He is at a meeting.
description: Both 'in' and 'at' can be used interchangeably but they can have slightly different meanings. Use 'in' when referring to the meeting as an activity without specifying location. 'he is in a meeting' means that he is in the midst of a group of people who are discussing something and he is actively involved in it. Use 'at' when referring to the meeting as a location or event. Also 'in a meeting' implies being on the same premises as the speaker. 'at a meeting' implies being on a different premises than the speaker.

proverb: I stayed home all day yesterday. I stayed at home all day yesterday.
description: Both these expressions are correct and can be used interchangeably. 'Home' is a word that rarely accepts a preposition. We say 'go home', 'come home', 'return home' etc. But we also say 'at home', 'from home', 'off home' and so on. Grammatically, when the preposition is used, the word 'home' becomes a NOUN. In 'stay home', it is an ADVERB, it describes the verb 'stay'

proverb: Do you see this? Are you seeing this?
description: 'see' can act both as a stative and as a dynamic verb, and it is used as a stative verb when talking about perception with the eyes or understanding. But sometimes you might hear native speakers say 'Are you seeing this?' instead of 'Do you see this?' or 'What are you seeing?' instead of 'What do you see?'. In modern spoken English both these questions are correct and can be used interchangeably. There is a slight difference between these two questions, but it's not the typical difference between present and present progressive tenses. It's more about how long the seeing has been taking place.
